PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Visit the booth for all your registration needs and conference questions.

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
There will be two shuttles running loops through all of the official hotels. There is a scheduled loop during the morning and evenings, and an on-demand shuttle through the rest of the day.
You can use our website to track where the shuttle is, shuttle.codemash.org. You can see where the shuttles are in real time.
The shuttle will pick up and drop off by Entrance A in the conference center (near the attendee registration booth and the giant lion). The shuttle will pick up and drop off by the main lobby doors of each hotel. The shuttles are available to attendees and their families.
Afternoon: (Expect a delay) Call for Pickup Complimentary service to area hotels. Call Kalahari Concierge for Pickup (FIFO) (419) 433-7200 x34089
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Shuttle

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Tuesday Breakfast
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Breakfast

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
A structured conversation about what we'll learn at CodeMash, what we'll do when we come home ... and whatever else we'd like to discover.
Grab coffee and meet in Salon F.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Lean Coffee (Day 1)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Visit the booth for all your registration needs and conference questions.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Registration Booth - Tuesday

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Come play the best starship bridge simulator you’ve even seen. Twice the awesome this year with twice as many bridges. Take over a touchscreen station to help your team beat the scenarios. No team? No problem, just drop in. We’ll match you up.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Artemis Bridge Simulator

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Drop in and play a game. Sponsored by Improving Enterprises. We also have Mayfair games back this year, with their giant sized versions of some of their most popular games.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Game Room

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Docker is a platform for building, shipping and running distributed applications. It solves the problem of managing an application's dependencies in a simple and automated way. Google, IBM, Red Hat, Amazon, and even Microsoft are all on board with it. This hands-on session will cover what Docker is, how to use it, and what it can do for you and your organization.
You will:
* Understand the purpose of Docker and the concepts of images, containers and repositories
* Install Docker on your laptop and run standard Docker images
* Learn strategies for building layered Docker images
* Create, run and debug your own Docker image
* Receive an overview of advanced Docker container concepts like volume mounting and IP port forwarding
* Be introduced to Fig (fast, isolated development environments) to easily manage a cluster of Docker containers
So come and get shipping with Docker!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Get Shipping with Docker

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Do you have a game idea that you’re itching to make a reality? Do you wish you knew HOW to make games so you could even start brainstorming ideas? Join gurus from Unity and Microsoft for a day of learning how to build and ship your first game! We will walk through the ins and outs of the Unity game engine by doing a hands on lab, followed by incorporating the Oculus Rift for a breathtakingly awesome experience. Once you’ve got that you’ll be ready to ship to multiple platforms, which of course we will show you how to do.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Get your game on with Unity and Oculus Rift! (Part 1)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Have you ever seen a holiday light show and thought, "Wow, I wish I could do that." In this half-day pre-compiler, you will build your very own relay controlled power supply. You will then learn how to connect and program the relays with a simple microcontroller. Finally, work as a team to synchronize a collection of holiday lights for your own holiday light show. Get ready to take on the Griswolds! *** There are two instances of this session. They are both the same. Seating is limited. Please visit our site (http://www.codemash.org/save-seat2/) to save a seat. There is a $60 fee for the bag full of electronics you will be taking home with you. ***
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Holiday Light Fight DIY (Instance 1)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Humanitarian Toolbox initiative is a sustainable, ongoing effort aimed at leveraging the expertise and generosity of the global technical community to build, maintain and package solutions needed by response organizations in time of crisis and recovery.
Developers can join us for this two day event to work on projects that have been requested by lead disaster relief organizations. Bring your skills. Write some Code. Save the world.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Humanitarian Toolbox Codeathon (Part 1)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
JavaScript has often been thought of as a toy language, used for tasks like enabling and disabling blink tags on your chihuahua’s website or making a dynamic web 2.0 todo list. While the core language has remained quirky and downright confusing at times, it has spread like a virus from the web to the server and into other aspects of your every day life. We’ll ignore the benefits and drawbacks of using JavaScript powered toasters for this precompiler and focus instead on server side development with Node.js.
This precompiler will not advocate the use of Node.js for every problem ever just because it is the new hawtness. While it may be hawt, and it may look good on your resume, it is not the best solution for all problems. We will openly discuss it’s strengths and weaknesses and focus in on the type of applications that make sense for Node.js. Specifically, this session will hone in on providing real time, two way communication between web clients and server side applications. If you have ever encountered this scenario, or think you might in the future, you should definitely think about leveraging the benefits of Node.js.
We'll use a structured curriculum to guide students through introductory aspects of Node.js, eventually building a realtime web socket solution that shows off it's true power. This precompiler assumes 0 knowledge of anything Node.js, although you may need a pair partner if you are not very familiar with the JavaScript programming language. Bring a laptop, a friend, and your brain, and walk away with a life-altering, mind-expanding experience (or at least enough Node.js knowledge to land a new job).
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Intro to Node.JS

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Wonder what all the Cloud Computing hype is about? Want to know how to deploy a standard Java web application to the cloud and get limitless scalability? Well, this hands on tutorial will answer all your questions and provide confidence by walking you through the process of deploying a sophisticated Java web application to the Amazon Web Service (AWS) Cloud.
During this tutorial you will provision clustered servers (EC2), relational database (EC2 and EBS), load balancer (Elastic Load Balancing), content delivery (Cloud Front) and how to monitor your whole infrastructure. Other Amazon Web Services will be demonstrated and discussed as appropriate. Note: An Amazon Web Services Account is a nice to have and will incur a minimal cost during the tutorial but is not a requirement. Access to AWS will be provided to you if you don’t already have access.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Java in the (Amazon) Cloud Workshop

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: JavaScript has quickly become the language to write code in that you want to be able to share between services on the web, in Windows, and on mobile devices. Join Jeff as he walks you through constructing a JavaScript application and development techniques allow you to migrate from ASP.NET and the web to Windows 8, Windows Phone, iOS, and Android. You'll see how to quickly JavaScript can be used cross-platform, and you'll learn how to take your SOLID development practices to another level by targeting every platform with your next application.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: JavaScript Everywhere - Learn to Build a Cross-platform JavaScript Application that Works EVERYWHERE (Part 1)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: The major cause of web insecurity is insecure software development practices. This introductory session will teach developers the basics when it comes to secure coding theory and practice. Any web developer will benefit from this session; defensive secure coding theory is trans-language and trans-framework. Simple topics like SQL Injection will be covered, but we will also do a deep dive into Authentication, User Interface Security, and SSL/TLS best practices.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Keeping the bad guys out: an introduction to application security

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Have you worked for people you thought were great leaders, but weren’t sure where they got that magic from? Have you seen people getting great results from their teams during difficult times—and wanted to be able to get similar success with your own teams? Do you want to take on more responsibility in your career, but aren’t sure how to get those opportunities?
Leadership 101 will help you answer some of those questions! Join Jim Holmes in this highly interactive workshop where you’ll learn some fundamental skills and gather some tools that can help you on your leadership journey. You’ll clarify what makes an effective leader, learn a few critical communication skills, and get tips on dealing with difficult people and situations.
You’ll leave this workshop with a better understanding of leveraging your strengths and mitigating your weaknesses. You’ll also take away approaches for ensuring you’re able to best empower your teams to do amazing things.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Leadership 101

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Armed with an Arduino, MacGyver-like circuitry, cheap wood, and JavaScript, can you rise to the call of battle? Engage your brain by building in three dimensions: software, electronics, and hardware. Innovate to give your bot the edge over your competition and battle for NodeBot supremacy. This precompiler is an all-day, hands-on, immersive experience. You don’t need to have any Node.js, hardware, or electronics experience — there will be coaches and pairs to work with you! Whose NodeBot will reign supreme? Feeling more like a pacifist? Compete in our MazeBot challenge instead. Don’t feel like competing? We’ll have all sorts of platforms, boards, components, supplies, etc for hacking robots however you want.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Node Bots (Instance 1, part 1)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: This year we have a dedicated hotel room near the conference for people who need someplace for prayer time, or a quiet place to handle some personal things (breast feeding, etc). Not for office/work duties. Check in at the reg booth for the room key.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Prayer & Quiet Room

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Python is a fun, dynamic, flexible language for solving all kinds of problems. It's used everywhere from modest scripts to large systems, powering things like websites, games, film production tools, scientific analysis, and even space programs. Best of all, it's a language that "fits your brain".
This session is a mostly self guided introduction to Python through koans. What’s a koan you ask? It’s a small puzzle or exercise expressed as a test, designed to build your knowledge of the Python syntax and idioms incrementally.
Students will be completing the exercises either with a partner or alone. This allows them to think through the exercise, giving a better foundation on which to build. We'll be there to explain what is happening and why your solution works as well as strategically intervening with relevant discussion about the koans.
Students are expected to bring a laptop pre installed with Git and Python (version 2.7 or 3.4).
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Python Koans - An Introduction To Python

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Scrum is simple… and also complex, easy to understand but difficult to implement.
Like chess, the rules are straightforward but mastering the game takes perseverance, patience, and most importantly, practice! This intensive half day workshop is for you if: you are completely new to Scrum and looking to get your feet wet; you are currently practicing Scrum and looking for a refresher; you are concerned that your current Scrum (but) implementation is missing the mark. Attend and learn Scrum the way the experts teach it, by working with a cross-functional team to deliver actual working software!
NOTE: Don't worry, deep technical knowledge is NOT required, just passion!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Scrumdamentals Workshop

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
How fast can you learn whether your product is going to be a hit or a dud?
Ever since the Agile Manifesto was drafted in February of 2001, the principles of agile software development have come to dominate the way we go about building systems. Over the last few years, an evolution of that agile thinking has emerged under the banner of Lean. Much like agile, the emphasis is on getting rapid feedback and embracing change. But where agile is primarily focused on how you go about building software the right way, lean thinking broadens that to ensure you’re building the right thing in the first place.
In this workshop, we’ll give you some practical experience in how to work lean. We’ll start by forming small cross-functional teams and ensure each has a product idea (either one of their own or one that is assigned). Then, each team will put into practice the lean practices that are designed to help you eliminate wasted time and effort in finding product/market fit. You’ll identify core underlying assumptions about the product/business. Then you’ll design and conduct experiments which can help you assess the validity of those assumptions. Based on what you learn, you’ll adjust the core idea and iterate until you have a product idea that is better than what you started with.
This is a great session for the technical and non-technical alike.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Working Lean

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Seriously! All the way to production! During this 8 hour session, we’ll walk you through the fundamentals of Android development. We’ll start at the very beginning, setting up a brand spankin' new project in Android Studio. At the end of the session you'll push your newly created app to the Google Play store.
We’ll be covering A LOT of material and we’ll be moving quickly! To make sure that folks don’t fall too far behind, we’ll be posting checkpoints and session material out on Github.
Come prepared to have fun, learn a ton, and build something awesome!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: You’re Going to Build an Android App at CodeMash! (Part 1)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Pretend you were taking part in a race to find a particular animal statue within the Kalahari given a list of all the animals and their location. If your list isn’t sorted, you’d have to use a strategy such as starting at the top and reading every entry until you find the one you wanted. This might be too time-consuming when there’s a race to be won!
Thankfully, computers excel at sorting lists. But how do they do that? In this highly interactive session, you will become the computer and, with the help of your friends, you’ll work through some of the basic sorting methods used in computer science. You’ll keep track of various metrics, such as the number of item comparisons required to get the data ordered correctly, so that you can determine how fast each method is under what conditions. By the end of this session, you’ll know exactly which technique you’d choose to sort that list and win that race!
And not to worry: No computer or Kalahari animal shall be used or harmed in the preparation or presentation of this dynamic session.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Sorting Safari

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
When you think about communication, you usually think about talking and listening. While this makes up most communication, there are a lot of other factors that we take for granted such body movements and context from our surroundings. Communication with computers is completely different. Computers are literal, only recognize certain languages, and can't fill in the gaps. In this session Matt will talk about different ways we communicate with computers with input devices and programming languages. Matt will also pretend to be a computer in an interactive programming session to make a sandwich, with hilarious consequences to literal translations of instructions.
Note that this session will be geared for ages 4-7. Let Matt know whether food allergies or diet prohibit a snack of wheat bread, sunflower seed butter, and grape jelly.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Talking to Computers (ages 4-7)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Tuesday Lunch
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Lunch

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: As developers, we focus on the utility and usability of the systems we build, as we should. There is another consideration, though, and that is the criminal element and its access to our systems. The most utile and usable system is dangerous to deploy without appropriate security controls in place. In this four hour bootcamp, you'll get a look at the security principles that will keep your systems more secure, learn to test for specific vulnerabilities, and put your new skills on the line using Burp Suite in a Capture The Flag competition that will run the entirety of CodeMash. The session will cover Authentication and Content Management, Injection Vulnerabilities, Cracking and Fixing REST APIs, and Data Security. This is a hands on session, so make sure to download the Virtual Machine at CodeMashCTF.com, or from the CodeMash FTP Server.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Break It Before You Buy It - Hacking and Fixing Web Applications

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Frontend projects are becoming more and more complex, pushing greater rules and requirements into the browser. We expect a lot from modern web applications (many run entirely in the browser), but we’re rarely writing tests to verify that our high expectations are met.
Come explore the magical world of Frontend Testing with the Sparkbox team. Together we will examine the pain points of developing without tests and look at some of our real-world examples. We’ll also talk about what you should and shouldn't test, and get our hands dirty with...
- Jasmine / CoffeeScript - Automating tests in the build process - Adding tests to existing code - Refactoring jQuery spaghetti - Handling AJAX requests and Promises - Coding for better tests - Running tests in a CI build
Prepare to receive the tools and techniques to build solid, tested frontend code. And don't worry—we'll talk about selling the concept to your team back home and gradually work it into your process.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Build Right: Frontend Testing

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Over the course of the workshop learn techniques related to building, maintaining, and scaling front-end style guides. Attendees will learn the history of style guides, see examples of great style guides done by small and large companies alike, and start building their own style guide.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Front-End Style Guides from 0 to 60!

Developers can join us for this two day event to work on projects that have been requested by lead disaster relief organizations. Bring your skills. Write some Code. Save the world.

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: As a developer you wanted to get your feet wet with Spring Framework but never had the time? As a Java developer you will get a chance to build a client / server application using the Spring Framework from end to end. This will focus on the latest version of Spring and some nice features like web and rest services, persistence, and transactional processing. The attendee should have a laptop ready to code some Java and Spring applications.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Introduction to Spring Framework

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: JavaScript has quickly become the language to write code in that you want to be able to share between services on the web, in Windows, and on mobile devices. Join Jeff as he walks you through constructing a JavaScript application and development techniques allow you to migrate from ASP.NET and the web to Windows 8, Windows Phone, iOS, and Android. You'll see how to quickly JavaScript can be used cross-platform, and you'll learn how to take your SOLID development practices to another level by targeting every platform with your next application.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: JavaScript Everywhere - Learn to Build a Cross-platform JavaScript Application that Works EVERYWHERE (Part 2)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
You are assigned to a small team to maintain and support an increasingly complex mars rover system. For mission critical systems, code quality is paramount. How will you issue commands, avoid obstacles, and fight off the newly discovered Martians without ending up with a fragile code base? Through a series of kata exercises you will have the opportunity to apply each of the SOLID principles of object-oriented design to handle all the new challenges that await as you explore a new world.
Participants should come prepared with their laptop and a development environment setup to work in either C# or Java. Code bases for these platforms will be provided.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Landing on SOLID ground : Surviving on Mars through better coding practices

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Armed with an Arduino, MacGyver-like circuitry, cheap wood, and JavaScript, can you rise to the call of battle? Engage your brain by building in three dimensions: software, electronics, and hardware. Innovate to give your bot the edge over your competition and battle for NodeBot supremacy. This precompiler is an all-day, hands-on, immersive experience. You don’t need to have any Node.js, hardware, or electronics experience — there will be coaches and pairs to work with you! Whose NodeBot will reign supreme? Feeling more like a pacifist? Compete in our MazeBot challenge instead. Don’t feel like competing? We’ll have all sorts of platforms, boards, components, supplies, etc for hacking robots however you want.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Node Bots (Instance 1, Part 2)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Whether you are building a full blown client-side MV* application, or sprinkling pieces of interactivity throughout an existing traditional server-side MVC application, AngularJS has something for you. We will start with an introduction to Angular fundamentals, follow up with some more advanced topics and finish the day showcasing techniques you can use to integrate Angular into your project regardless of server-side technology.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Practical AngularJS

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Nearly 6 years ago to the day, Martin Fowler wrote of "Flaccid Scrum" to bring urgency to an increasing percentage of Scrum that sought only to "do" Scrum, but failed to adopt strong technical practices or learn advanced techniques. It turns out that Scrum by itself is not enough to reach high performance! In this highly collaborative half day session, we will seek to fill in the gaps intentionally left in the Scrum framework. You determine the agenda! We will be facilitating conversations around Lean, measuring team productivity, continuous delivery, test automation, DevOps, advanced scaling techniques, and much more!
NOTE: New to Scrum? Consider attending the Scrumdamentals Workshop to gain a solid baseline of Scrum knowledge.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Scrum is not enough! Advanced techniques for achieving high performance.

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Get up to speed on web development with Python, the language that "fits your brain," and Django, the web framework "for perfectionists with deadlines." We'll strengthen your Python muscles by guiding you through the construction of a full website using modern Django idioms that make things like user registration and CRUD apps a breeze.
Attendees should bring a laptop with Python (2.7 or 3.4) and Git already installed. Some previous Python experience will be helpful but not required; newcomers to Python should plan to pair with a more experienced Pythonista.
Setup instructions and slides will be available at https://github.com/mpirnat/django-tutorial-v2.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Web Development with Python and Django

Seriously! All the way to production! During this 8 hour session, we’ll walk you through the fundamentals of Android development. We’ll be covering A LOT of material and we’ll be moving quickly! To make sure that folks don’t fall too far behind, we’ll be posting checkpoints and session material out on Github.

PublicSessionDataModel.Title: You’re Going to Build an Android App at CodeMash! (Part 2)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Make a tetrahedron with 6 toothpick. Make 4 of these and you have one 2 high. Make 4 of these and you have one 4 high. Make 4 of these and you have one 8 high. Make 4 of these and you have one 16 high. Within an short time, we can have one as tall as a child.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Kidz-in-3D

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: In this session we will go over parts of a computer, rules for online safety, and how to use various types of application. It is highly recommended that attendees bring a computer with a spreadsheet application, painting or drawing application (paint would be fine). This session will cover the requirements to complete the Cub Scouts Computers Belt Loop and Pin. There may be additional effort needed after the session to fulfill the requirements.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Bits, Parts, Safety and Apps

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: (102min) (PG) Bring a beverage. Popcorn will be provided
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: KM Movie: Frozen

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Come to this 'Pre-compiler' event at the water-park.
Why should the parents have to have all the fun programming? Bring your little ones, and let them experience some of the fun and excitement of programming. The your little ones can experience the joy of being in Control of Mom or Dad.
Little Ones: Control your parents. Watch your parent execute commands such as step, swim, splash, fall. Make them power your inner tube, and go in the direction you want.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Kidz-In-Control, Water-park Edition (1)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
In 2212, during the height of the Unakalhai Uprising, a force of rebels (“Redshirts”) has seized the Space Station Asimov in order to use it as a forward base against the Terran Stellar Navy (TSN, aka “Bluebellies) of the United Space Faring Planets (USFP). The TSN has sent the Artemis-class Battleship Artemis and the Kiev-class Light Cruiser Intrepid to the nearby Command Station Campbell in order to retake the station. Expecting to face a few inferior rebel ships protecting the station, the two TSN ships discover only fleets from the other interstellar governments closing on the stations.
On the plus side, Asimov Station’s shields are offline. The Artemis must dock with the station and drop off a squad of Space Marines while the shields are down. These Space Marines must infiltrate the rebel station, complete their mission, and exfiltrate via one of the starships before the rebels can get the shields back online. Meanwhile, the two starships must fend off the alien fleets in order to buy the Marines time to complete their mission.
Gameplay Overview: This will be an Artemis-Integrated Live Action Scenario Game for up to 24 players per run. Each run will last 90 minutes and will include team selection, training, and scenario play. Players will be randomly selected to be on one of four teams: Alpha, Bravo, Charlie and Delta. Alpha and Bravo will consist of six players each which will be the bridge crews of the Artemis (Alpha) and the Intrepid (Bravo). The six players of Charlie team will be the Space Marines, and the six players of Delta will be the rebel defenders. Charlie and Delta teams will be given laser tag rifles to simulate combat. All teams will be given more details and training at the time of the event.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Incident at Asimov Station (#1)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
There will be two shuttles running loops through all of the official hotels. There is a scheduled loop during the morning and evenings, and an on-demand shuttle through the rest of the day.
You can use our website to track where the shuttle is, shuttle.codemash.org. You can see where the shuttles are in real time.
The shuttle will pick up and drop off by Entrance A in the conference center (near the attendee registration booth and the giant lion). The shuttle will pick up and drop off by the main lobby doors of each hotel. The shuttles are available to attendees and their families.
Afternoon: (Expect a delay) Call for Pickup Complimentary service to area hotels. Call Kalahari Concierge for Pickup (FIFO) (419) 433-7200 x34089

All teams will be given more details and training at the time of the event.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Incident at Asimov Station (#3)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
There will be two shuttles running loops through all of the official hotels. There is a scheduled loop during the morning and evenings, and an on-demand shuttle through the rest of the day.
You can use our website to track where the shuttle is, shuttle.codemash.org. You can see where the shuttles are in real time.
The shuttle will pick up and drop off by Entrance A in the conference center (near the attendee registration booth and the giant lion). The shuttle will pick up and drop off by the main lobby doors of each hotel. The shuttles are available to attendees and their families.
Afternoon: (Expect a delay) Call for Pickup Complimentary service to area hotels. Call Kalahari Concierge for Pickup (FIFO) (419) 433-7200 x34089
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Shuttle

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Wednesday Breakfast
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Breakfast

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
A structured conversation about what we'll learn at CodeMash, what we'll do when we come home ... and whatever else we'd like to discover.
Grab coffee and meet in Rosewood.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Lean Coffee (Day 2)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Visit the booth for all your registration needs and conference questions.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Registration Booth - Wednesday

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Think you know LINQ? It's 2015, of course you do... at least, you probably know how to use it... so long as you stick to the standard operators, of course. But how does it *really* work? What's lurking beneath the calm surface of lambda expressions?
LINQ may feel a bit retro now, with C# 6 on the horizon, but it's a fascinating topic to dig into... then dig further... and further.
Thrill to see query expressions converted into normal C#! Swoon over the complex state machine generated by a simple iterator block! Gasp at the nuances of optimizing lazily-evaluated sequences! Rejoice as your own code extends LINQ to Objects seamlessly!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Adventures in LINQ: party like it's 2007 (Part 1)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Rust is a new systems programming language focused on safety and speed. This precompiler will give you a thorough understandings of the core ideas of Rust, and then move into the more complex parts. Afterward, you should have no problems writing your own Rust programs and libraries.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: An Introduction to Rust

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Come play the best starship bridge simulator you’ve even seen. Twice the awesome this year with twice as many bridges. Take over a touchscreen station to help your team beat the scenarios. No team? No problem, just drop in. We’ll match you up.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Artemis Bridge Simulator

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
You know you want to create a game like Angry Birds that allows you to fling your manager's head into boiling lava! With only a laptop running Windows and an HTML-5 capable browser, you can create wicked-cool games for iOS, Android, and Windows. Start from scratch or build on templates to create shooters, platformers, side-runners, physics puzzles, driving games, and more without having to code your own physics engine. In this workshop, beginning and experienced developers alike will learn Construct 2 (from Scirra) with plenty of hands-on time to build a compelling, addictive game!
Under the covers, this tool uses HTML5 and JavaScript. This makes it easy and fun for beginners to create games, and more advanced developers can rapidly prototype games and dive into the underlying HTML5 and JavaScript.
Please bring a laptop running Windows with an HTML5-capable browser.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Develop a Cross-Platform 2D Game: Hands-on Workshop (Part 1)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: This. four hour open hack session will be a chance for you to get your hands dirty in a mini game jam with provided Oculus Rifts. Nathalie will open the session with some demos of integrating the Oculus Rift into games built with Unity, and also be on hand to overlord the hacking. While beginners are welcome, it would be useful if you had some basic knowledge of using Unity (which you could get from attending the Unity Precompiler session.) Come with ideas, games you’ve started but never finished, and/or your finished game that you’d love to see through the Oculus Rift. Teams can be formed during or prior to the session. Please come prepared with Unity installed on your machine.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Down the rabbit hole and through the Rift

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Drop in and play a game. Sponsored by Improving Enterprises. We also have Mayfair games back this year, with their giant sized versions of some of their most popular games.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Game Room

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
I don’t know about you, but vanilla CSS always leaves me wanting more. It’s a fairly simple language, can do some pretty powerful things, but after a while... well, it can become rather tedious to work with.
Enter Sass: Syntactically Awesome Stylesheets. Sass is a CSS meta-language and precompiler that makes the prettification of your website a breeze by adding invaluable features of more traditional programming languages.
In this workshop, we’ll jump right in to the Sass workflow and cover all the key game changers - nesting, variables, mixins, inheritance, and directives. We’ll also cover some of the gotchyas, tools and extensions, and tips on organization and coding standards.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Getting Sassy With CSS : Sass Shop (Part 1)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Breaking free from the confines of the cubicle farm and going out on your own can be one of the most satisfying things you do for your career. It can also be one of the most terrifying. Being on your own can seem like it's nothing but ponies, unicorns and rainbows, but it's a lot of work, and success is not guaranteed.
Mike, an independent developer since 2001, will discuss the lesson's he's learned over the years along with the ups and downs he's experienced. In this updated and expanded session, he will be joined by friend and attorney Jeffrey Strauss to help answer the most common questions he's been asked over the years. "How do I get started?", "Where do I find clients?", "How much do I charge?", "Do I need a contract?" and many others. Bring your questions and find out if the grass really is greener on the other side.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Going Indie 101: Lessons Learned from a Over a Decade of Independence (Part 1)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Developers have plenty of information and insights to share yet often shy away from writing books due to the common belief it’s not possible to make money in publishing. This is nonsense, particularly at a time when the opportunities for self-publishing have never been greater thanks to an explosion of available tools and services. In this 1/2 day seminar bestselling author Jason Gilmore will introduce you to the process, techniques and technologies he’s used to successfully publish several very popular programming books.
You’ll learn how to identify a market-worthy topic, build a list of interested customers before you’ve even written a word, create and execute a sane writing schedule, convert your manuscript into a professional, polished book, and sell your book through key channels such as Amazon.com, iBooks, Google Play and Leanpub. Jason will illustrate the concepts discussed throughout with real-world examples and data drawn upon his own self-publishing experience, and additionally furnish a wealth of information for those attendees also interested in publishing through traditional channels.
We'll also work through the process of creating a new book draft inside Leanpub, effectively clearing away the first major barrier towards publishing your book. You will walk away with a well-rounded understanding of the publishing process, and should you decide take the plunge you will know exactly what steps to take to turn your idea into a book!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: How to Write and Self-Publish a Financially Successful Tech book

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: In this interactive session, you'll learn some of the basic principles and practices of writing better quality code: testing and pairing. You'll work with a variety of partners on coding katas designed to instill best practices that you'll then be ready to apply when next you work on production code. This session is led by the organizers of the Hudson Software Craftsmanship group and provides a great introduction to the afternoon's Improving Software Craftsmanship, Intermediate Edition session (though this is not a prerequisite for that session).
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Improving Software Craftsmanship for Beginners

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
As an industry we are collecting more and more data. At some point we have to be able to make sense of the data. Unfortunately many of the tools we have historically used can not scale up to the terabytes and petabytes we have captured. Hadoop is one of those relatively new technologies that is taking the industry by storm since it has proven to scale by taking advantage of the MapReduce pattern and distributed computing.
During this hands-on tutorial you will provision a Hadoop cluster, write MapReduce jobs and learn how to store and access data via Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS). You will also learn how cloud providers such as Amazon Web Services’ Elastic MapReduce (EMR) and Microsoft’s Azure HDInsight provide Hadoop as a service.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Introduction to Hadoop

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Metaprogramming is the arching principle for techniques where code does more than the strict interpretation of the computer language. It encompasses strategies as diverse as code generation, Aspect Oriented Programming (AOP), Domain Specific Languages (DSL), and runtime code creation. The new .NET Compiler as a Service (Roslyn) opens up opportunities in metaprogramming by making it practical to explore and create syntactic and semantic trees. This day starts with metaprogramming principles and an overview of techniques. The afternoon dives deep into a single easily accomplished approach to metaprogramming – code generation. You’ll learn how to think about your code as a set of patterns, unique input to those patterns and handcrafted customizations. You’ll learn more about working with the complexities of the Roslyn trees and creating custom built interfaces to simplify access to the information, for a specific purpose. You’ll leave able to create strongly typed code-first style input to your own templates and provide rich customization points that maintain application integrity. Use these techniques to remove the boring, stupid parts of application development.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Metaprogramming on the .NET Platform (Part 1)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Armed with an Arduino, MacGyver-like circuitry, cheap wood, and JavaScript, can you rise to the call of battle? Engage your brain by building in three dimensions: software, electronics, and hardware. Innovate to give your bot the edge over your competition and battle for NodeBot supremacy. This precompiler is an all-day, hands-on, immersive experience. You don’t need to have any Node.js, hardware, or electronics experience — there will be coaches and pairs to work with you! Whose NodeBot will reign supreme? Feeling more like a pacifist? Compete in our MazeBot challenge instead. Don’t feel like competing? We’ll have all sorts of platforms, boards, components, supplies, etc for hacking robots however you want.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Node Bots (Instance 2, Part 1)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: This year we have a dedicated hotel room near the conference for people who need someplace for prayer time, or a quiet place to handle some personal things (breast feeding, etc). Not for office/work duties. Check in at the reg booth for the room key.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Prayer & Quiet Room

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Are you tired of TDD workshops that make you do boring things like calculate bowling scores and prime factors or demonstrate how to win at the game of life? If so, this is the session for you! In this TDD workshop we will be building the domain model for EverCraft -- a new MMORPG from Blizzards of the Coast. We have lots of story cards prepared covering features from combat to magic, classes to spells, and races to items. Plus, we'll be defining some of these cards during the session in case you want that +9 knife of ogre slaying or enjoy casting magic missile at the darkness.
This workshop is language agnostic and for all levels of developers. The focus is on TDD and emergent design but pair programming will be covered as well. The only requirement is that you bring a laptop and that you be able to test-drive you code with your language of choice. When you are done you will emerge a better programmer for the experience but there is small chance you will have a craving for Cheetos and Mountain Dew.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Putting the D&D in TDD (Part 1)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: The major cause of web insecurity is insecure software development practices. This session will teach developers how to prevent various web layers attacks from being successful. We will cover Cross Site Request Forgery, Clickjacking, Access Control Design, App-layer intrusion detection and other topics relevant to the developer who wants to build secure and robust applications. Developers from any language or background will benefit.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Stopping the bad guys at the front door

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: The art of building software combines understanding the value it creates and capturing the vision of the user. The best tool developed, thus far, to capture these needs is a Story Map, a tool that is both easily learned and easily implemented. Join us to learn how to build a Story Map, break down that map into story cards, and advance through a process that will provide the details essential to successful development and execution of a project.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Story Mapping Made Real

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
This session lays out the fundamentals of working with automated functional testing. We’ll start with discussing how important clear acceptance criteria are, then do practical implementations of functional tests dealing with common situations such as input validation, AJAX delays, and yes, downloading Zip files.
Along the way you’ll pick up critical concepts like dealing with a web page’s DOM, element locators, and tools to help you interact with these. You’ll also learn UI automation programming concepts like the Page Object Pattern, implicit and explicit waits, and modularizing your tests.
You’ll also learn why testing at the UI isn’t enough—and you’ll learn how to build helper APIs to handle true testing heuristics as part of your tests.
Additionally, you’ll see where you need to work together with developers to create a system that’s more easily testable. We’ll walk through simple changes you can make to your UI, and we’ll look at how turning off features like CAPTCHA can ease your testing woes and dramatically decrease your scotch consumption.
This session focuses primarily on automating web tests, but many of the same concepts can be applied to other UI environments too. Demos and labs will be in C# using WebDriver, but we’ll also discuss Watir, MS Web Test, and Telerik’s Test Studio. You’ll also learn how Jeff Morgan’s page_objects gem might be a great fit for your environment if you’re working with Ruby. We'll briefly cover acceptance tools like Fitness and Cucumber, and how they can bring great value to your process, too.
You’ll leave this session having learned how to deal with functional testing from A to Z. You’ll also learn critical factors for success in keeping your tests running quickly, and avoiding brittle tests that break frequently.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Web UI Testing from Acceptance Criteria to Zip Files (Part 1)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Why should the parents have to have all the fun programming? Bring your kids, and let them experience some of the fun and excitement of programming.
The young ones can experience the joy of being in control, and giving out commands, to a human robot (the parent) using a simple program of Step, Right, Left.
Kids: Control your parents. Make them do what you want. Race your parents against others! We will explore writing a program, test, edit, run, repeat.
Come and get your "Parent" "remote control" (actually a paper remote).
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Kidz-In-More-Control

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: How does a computer count? How does it verify whether data is valid? What method could it use to reduce the size of an image file so it takes less space on disk while not losing any information about the image? In this highly interactive session, you will get a chance to become the computer as you are introduced to the binary system, data compression, encryption, and other basic concepts of Computer Science.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Computer Science 101

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Wednesday Lunch
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Lunch

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: It can be difficult to know how and where to get started with the Microsoft Azure platform due to the rapid pace of innovation. In this workshop you will learn about a range of commonly used services within Azure, as well as a battle tested insights into creating defensive architectures for the cloud. Come with a laptop ready to learn and complete a hands-on exercises that will walk you through building and deploying an application that leverages multiple Azure services. Leave the workshop with knowledge of various hosting options in Azure, experience in deploying a solution, and lessons in designing your solutions to protect against failure.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: A Lap Around the Cloud with Microsoft Azure

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: You know about Hadoop, you've got no-SQL and Graph DBs licked, but you're wondering... What next? In this session, we'll go beyond the introductory level talks and delve into basic statistics, linear regression, logistic regression, Bayesian classification and Hadoop for the Microsoft developer.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Advanced Big Data Tools

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Learn to create cross platform mobile applications for iOS, Android and Windows Phone, with Xamarin.Forms. This four-hour hands-on session will introduce Pages, Layouts and Views and will help you become comfortable with navigation and data handling. Join Xamarin Certified Developer, Jesse Liberty in this exploration of the new Xamarin.Forms library, and learn why this may be the future of Mobile Development.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Cross Platform Mobile Programming with Xamarin.Forms

PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Going Indie 101: Lessons Learned from a Over a Decade of Independence (Part 2)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Join your peers and fellow craftsmen in a variety of coding kata and exercises designed to improve your skills as software developers. Led by the organizers of the Hudson Software Craftsmanship group, this interactive session will help you sharpen your tools and learn from others. Experienced developers from all backgrounds are welcome, as are beginners (who might consider attending the morning's Improving Software Craftsmanship for Beginners session, though it's not required). Attendees should already be comfortable with a programming language of their choice and if possible should bring along a laptop computer with their development tools installed, including a unit test tool. This session will focus on group/pair design, refactoring, and application of design patterns to improve the design of existing software.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Improving Software Craftsmanship, Intermediate Edition

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
There’s a ton of buzz and hype around the internet of things (IoT) but what is it actually? IoT is the next evolution of distributed and connected systems at scale. It’s more than just connecting your phone to your thermostat, it’s about connected systems at scale so devices and people can interact in ways that was the realm of sci-fi just a few years ago. It gets interesting when devices are connected and able to inform and act based on their own environment and from an outside perspective, the world is just a smarter place.
In this session, we’ll discuss what IoT actually means and how it’s different (or not) from the connected systems of the past. Then we’ll dive into some code and demos to get a handful of devices up and running and connected to a cloud system where we can start applying machine learning to the telemetry data and start making intelligent decisions and take actions based on our learnings.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Making our world a smarter place with IoT

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Dynamic languages promise infinite flexibility, but at what cost? Tired of bugs that are only discovered at runtime, after being shipped to production? Your users are.
Learn how Rust balances speed and safety by learning from the mistakes of 50 years of computer science history. Safety and flexibility are not incompatible goals. High level APIs and JSON parsing are not limited to dynamic languages written 20 years ago.
Rust 1.0 is hot off the presses. Jump start your skills by learning everything you need to know in order to start producing production ready Rust binaries.
*No previous exposure to Rust required.*
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Rust or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Compiler

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
This is a beginners class to start developing iPhone or iPod applications using iOS. Just bring your Mac laptop installed with Yosemite and Xcode 6 and you will create your first "Hello World!" application in the first hour of the day.
This session will give you the knowledge to start building iOS applications. It will also give you the understanding of terminology to help follow along on other online training or presentations at the local CocoaHeads groups. Each topic includes some instruction time and some hands-on lab time. The material presented will also be available after the class has completed.
This introduction class was designed by Don Miller (GroundSpeed™) using his consulting background and teaching experience for his iOS development class at the University of Toledo.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Swiftly Breaking Ground with iOS Development

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: This session lays out the fundamentals of working with automated functional testing. We’ll start with discussing how important clear acceptance criteria are, then do practical implementations of functional tests dealing with common situations such as input validation, AJAX delays, and yes, downloading Zip files.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Web UI Testing from Acceptance Criteria to Zip Files (Part 2)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Show Mom she is really special with a popup card that lights up. Making a popup card is easier then you might think. What could be cooler then adding a LED light to the card?
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Popup LED Heart Card

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
When you think about communication, you usually think about talking and listening. While this makes up most communication, there are a lot of other factors that we take for granted such body movements and context from our surroundings. Communication with computers is completely different. Computers are literal, only recognize certain languages, and can't fill in the gaps. In this session Matt will talk about different ways we communicate with computers with input devices and programming languages. Matt will also pretend to be a computer in an interactive programming session to make a sandwich, with hilarious consequences to literal translations of instructions. We will also play a game where blindfolded attendees are given instructions by other attendees to complete a task.
Note that this session will be geared for ages 8-12. Let Matt know whether food allergies or diet prohibit a snack of wheat bread, sunflower seed butter, and grape jelly.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Talking to Computers (ages 8-12)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: (97 min) (PG) Bring a beverage. Popcorn will be provided
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: KM Movie: Rise of the Guardians

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
In 2212, during the height of the Unakalhai Uprising, a force of rebels (“Redshirts”) has seized the Space Station Asimov in order to use it as a forward base against the Terran Stellar Navy (TSN, aka “Bluebellies) of the United Space Faring Planets (USFP). The TSN has sent the Artemis-class Battleship Artemis and the Kiev-class Light Cruiser Intrepid to the nearby Command Station Campbell in order to retake the station. Expecting to face a few inferior rebel ships protecting the station, the two TSN ships discover only fleets from the other interstellar governments closing on the stations.
On the plus side, Asimov Station’s shields are offline. The Artemis must dock with the station and drop off a squad of Space Marines while the shields are down. These Space Marines must infiltrate the rebel station, complete their mission, and exfiltrate via one of the starships before the rebels can get the shields back online. Meanwhile, the two starships must fend off the alien fleets in order to buy the Marines time to complete their mission.
Gameplay Overview: This will be an Artemis-Integrated Live Action Scenario Game for up to 24 players per run. Each run will last 90 minutes and will include team selection, training, and scenario play. Players will be randomly selected to be on one of four teams: Alpha, Bravo, Charlie and Delta. Alpha and Bravo will consist of six players each which will be the bridge crews of the Artemis (Alpha) and the Intrepid (Bravo). The six players of Charlie team will be the Space Marines, and the six players of Delta will be the rebel defenders. Charlie and Delta teams will be given laser tag rifles to simulate combat. All teams will be given more details and training at the time of the event.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Incident at Asimov Station (#4)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Hey Little (and Big) ones, join, if you dare, Aydin your tour guide, on an adventure down the Scary Kalahari River! Explore, for the first time ever, the (Humorously) Scary areas of the Kalahari. Join us, sitting in giant Cheerios, on this interactive journey down the Lazy River. Not only Hear the stories, but also feel and interact with them. Have you felt the sneeze of a Kalahari Giant? How about the Kalahari Drooling Ghosts? Have you heard the stories about the Kalahari Snakes? Join us, at the Cabanaz to start our journey!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Scary Stories of the Kalahari River

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Whether you’ve been at CodeMash for two days, or just arriving, drop by the main dining hall to check out the lightning talks. A quick succession of six minute talks, over a wide variety of topics. Anyone can get on the list.

The shuttle will pick up and drop off by Entrance A in the conference center (near the attendee registration booth and the giant lion). The shuttle will pick up and drop off by the main lobby doors of each hotel. The shuttles are available to attendees and their families.
Afternoon: (Expect a delay) Call for Pickup Complimentary service to area hotels. Call Kalahari Concierge for Pickup (FIFO) (419) 433-7200 x34089
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Shuttle

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
In 2212, during the height of the Unakalhai Uprising, a force of rebels (“Redshirts”) has seized the Space Station Asimov in order to use it as a forward base against the Terran Stellar Navy (TSN, aka “Bluebellies) of the United Space Faring Planets (USFP). The TSN has sent the Artemis-class Battleship Artemis and the Kiev-class Light Cruiser Intrepid to the nearby Command Station Campbell in order to retake the station. Expecting to face a few inferior rebel ships protecting the station, the two TSN ships discover only fleets from the other interstellar governments closing on the stations.
On the plus side, Asimov Station’s shields are offline. The Artemis must dock with the station and drop off a squad of Space Marines while the shields are down. These Space Marines must infiltrate the rebel station, complete their mission, and exfiltrate via one of the starships before the rebels can get the shields back online. Meanwhile, the two starships must fend off the alien fleets in order to buy the Marines time to complete their mission.
Gameplay Overview: This will be an Artemis-Integrated Live Action Scenario Game for up to 24 players per run. Each run will last 90 minutes and will include team selection, training, and scenario play. Players will be randomly selected to be on one of four teams: Alpha, Bravo, Charlie and Delta. Alpha and Bravo will consist of six players each which will be the bridge crews of the Artemis (Alpha) and the Intrepid (Bravo). The six players of Charlie team will be the Space Marines, and the six players of Delta will be the rebel defenders. Charlie and Delta teams will be given laser tag rifles to simulate combat. All teams will be given more details and training at the time of the event.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Incident at Asimov Station (#5)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Would you like a peek at the 2015 game releases for Mayfair? Stop by at see what we’re cooking up!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Mayfair Sneak Peek

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Come hang out with the speakers and chat with them about the sessions you are most excited about. Speakers will have differently colored name badges on. Enjoy the music of the Womack Family Band, and a cash bar.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Speaker Reception (Open to all)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
In 2212, during the height of the Unakalhai Uprising, a force of rebels (“Redshirts”) has seized the Space Station Asimov in order to use it as a forward base against the Terran Stellar Navy (TSN, aka “Bluebellies) of the United Space Faring Planets (USFP). The TSN has sent the Artemis-class Battleship Artemis and the Kiev-class Light Cruiser Intrepid to the nearby Command Station Campbell in order to retake the station. Expecting to face a few inferior rebel ships protecting the station, the two TSN ships discover only fleets from the other interstellar governments closing on the stations.
On the plus side, Asimov Station’s shields are offline. The Artemis must dock with the station and drop off a squad of Space Marines while the shields are down. These Space Marines must infiltrate the rebel station, complete their mission, and exfiltrate via one of the starships before the rebels can get the shields back online. Meanwhile, the two starships must fend off the alien fleets in order to buy the Marines time to complete their mission.
Gameplay Overview: This will be an Artemis-Integrated Live Action Scenario Game for up to 24 players per run. Each run will last 90 minutes and will include team selection, training, and scenario play. Players will be randomly selected to be on one of four teams: Alpha, Bravo, Charlie and Delta. Alpha and Bravo will consist of six players each which will be the bridge crews of the Artemis (Alpha) and the Intrepid (Bravo). The six players of Charlie team will be the Space Marines, and the six players of Delta will be the rebel defenders. Charlie and Delta teams will be given laser tag rifles to simulate combat. All teams will be given more details and training at the time of the event.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Incident at Asimov Station (#6)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
There will be two shuttles running loops through all of the official hotels. There is a scheduled loop during the morning and evenings, and an on-demand shuttle through the rest of the day.
You can use our website to track where the shuttle is, shuttle.codemash.org. You can see where the shuttles are in real time.
The shuttle will pick up and drop off by Entrance A in the conference center (near the attendee registration booth and the giant lion). The shuttle will pick up and drop off by the main lobby doors of each hotel. The shuttles are available to attendees and their families.
Afternoon: (Expect a delay) Call for Pickup Complimentary service to area hotels. Call Kalahari Concierge for Pickup (FIFO) (419) 433-7200 x34089
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Shuttle

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Thursday Breakfast
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Breakfast

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
A structured conversation about what we'll learn at CodeMash, what we'll do when we come home ... and whatever else we'd like to discover.
Grab coffee and meet in Rosewood.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Lean Coffee (Day 3)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Visit the booth for all your registration needs and conference questions.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Registration Booth - Thursday

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Come play the best starship bridge simulator you’ve even seen. Twice the awesome this year with twice as many bridges. Take over a touchscreen station to help your team beat the scenarios. No team? No problem, just drop in. We’ll match you up.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Artemis

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Let’s explore how Continuous Integration combined with Automated Acceptance Testing can be integrated into an iOS Mobile Developer Team’s Agile process. The integration is intended to improve code quality and increase project margin. We will investigate how Apple Development build tools, combined with Objective-C/Swift Open Source projects, combined with Jenkins CI, can make an iOS Native Mobile Developer’s dream setup come true. We’ll show how when you combine all this, you can release faster, strong and more often. Bring your own Mac and Xcode. Slides, sample code, and fun will be provided. Be sure you're registered for Github too.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Automated Testing and Processes for your iOS Agile Team

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Today‘s apps contain a lot of moving parts, and juggling this complexity is what makes or breaks the user experience. In order to keep our sanity and reduce the amount of bugs that get shipped, we need to raise our level of abstraction.
ReactiveCocoa (RAC) is a framework that brings the (functional) reactive programming world into the grossly imperative land of iOS. It builds off of Cocoa's own key-value observing mechanism to provide a high-level, declarative API for composing operations on streams of data, state, and asynchronous tasks. You’ll leave this session with a solid foundation of RAC and how one can apply it in conjunction with powerful tools like MVVM to build applications.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Be proactive, use reactive!

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
While many talks provide a high level overview of a few components of the Azure platform, this session will provide real-world examples of how we utilize Azure on real-world, highly scalable applications.
Key areas we will demonstrate and discuss include:
• General scalability and moving a heavy amount of workload off the web servers • Using the Azure Service Bus to communicate between our front-end web servers and our back-end worker roles • Azure’s caching options and how we utilize them to serve a significant amount of data to clients out of memory and to support things such as ASP.NET Session State. • Using Blob Storage as an effectively unlimited amount of file storage. • Our usage of newer features such as the scheduler, mobile notifications, and auto scaling. • Our development and deployment process surrounding Azure based applications
This session, while only an hour long, will walk through a lot of code and tooling to show how we have leaned on Azure to solve a number of architectural headaches.
If you are using (or considering using) Azure as the foundation for your own applications, this session would be a great place to get ideas on where you should start.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Building Highly Scalable Apps on the Azure Platform: Real World Guidance

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Look for the reserved waterpark cabanas for attendees and their families. Great place to drop your gear, meet other attendees (or CodeMash families), and hang out.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Cabanas

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Google is on board with Docker. As is IBM, Red Hat, and Amazon. Even Microsoft has joined the crew! What is Docker, why is it making a big splash in the developer community and how can it make your life easier? Come to this session and find out!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Docker – Introduction to Lightweight Virtualization

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Elixir is a functional programming language on top of the Erlang VM. It has the power of Erlang but in a modern, elegant, and beautiful form. Elixir makes it easy to write highly distributed systems in a reliable and scalable manner. This presentation will introduce the language and the tools to let you immediately write Elixir programs. Concepts introduced include modules, control and data structures, pattern matching, recursions, pipes (really cool), functional operations, and distributed messaging. We will avoid the classic functional jargon and concentrate on the productive side of the language. While showing these concepts, we will use the repl, the build tool, and unit testing. The session will include many pre-written code examples and will encourage audience participation. By the end of the presentation, it is hoped that you will be as excited about the language as the the presenter is.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Elixir For The Impatient

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Drop in and play a game. Sponsored by Improving Enterprises. We also have Mayfair games back this year, with their giant sized versions of some of their most popular games.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Game Room

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: All .NET developers have used generics, but too few utilize their full power. Most developers who use generics think of them only for collections, when they are valuable in any situation where code is the same except for type. This session is a deep dive into generic classes, interfaces, methods, and delegates. You will learn how to increase the power of generics by applying constraints, and will see examples drawn from real applications. You will leave with ideas about how to apply generics in your development and understanding the .NET features necessary to realize those ideas.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Generics in .NET

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: An interview too often feels like a first date - awkward, strange, and not entirely predictive of what’s to follow. There are countless books and websites to help you when you’re a job seeker, but what about when you’re the one doing the hiring? Will you just ask the same puzzle questions or sort algorithm problems? What are your metrics for evaluating or contextualizing the answers? In this talk, I’ll discuss successful practices and techniques to help you find someone who will innovate your business, bring new energy to your team, get the work done, AND be someone you’ll want to work with.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: How To Interview (and Why)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Ruby is well-known for its powerful object-oriented features. Less well-known is that it also includes all the features you need to code in a purely functional style. This talk will start with a description of functional techniques including higher-order functions, partial function application, recursion, and use of immutable data structures. You'll see how Ruby 2's lazy enumerators can speed up your code, often dramatically. Finally, you'll see how to combine these techniques into an idiomatic functional style through demonstration of a clever algorithmic video game solver.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Life after OO: Functional Programming in Ruby

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: The use of this room varies, but it’s filled with lots of furniture. Drop in and hang out.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Lounge

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: If you’ve only spent a small amount of time in an airport, then you may have missed the tight orchestration it takes to get you - and your bags - from Point A to Point B. You seem to go from one line to the next - waiting for your turn to be processed. Getting your boarding pass in one line, x-rayed in another, snacks in another. Each line you stand in is completely unrelated to all the other lines, yet, they each play an important role in the overall process of getting you to your destination. Building scaleable distributed applications has many of those same characteristics. Seemingly disjointed, independent processes that work together to perform a larger function. This talk will focus on the design characteristics of this approach and include some real world examples using Golang, Docker & RabbitMQ - though this technique is tool agnostic. The airport metaphor will be stretched to the limit and there are sure to be some groan-worthy examples.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Modeling Your Applications Based on Airport Operations. Yes, even the TSA Part.

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Cross Site Scripting Defense is difficult. The Java Programming language does not provide native key defenses necessary to thoroughly prevent XSS. As technologies such as Content Security Policy emerge, we still need pragmatic advice to stop XSS in legacy applications as well as new applications using traditional Java frameworks. First generation encoding libraries had both performance and completeness problems that prevent developers from through, production-safe XSS defense. This talk will deeply review the OWASP Java Encoder Project and the OWASP HTML Sanitizer Project and give detailed code samples highlighting their use. Additional advice on next-generation JavaScript and JSON workflows using the OWASP JSON Sanitizer will also be reviewed.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Next Generation XSS Defense with Java

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Open spaces are available all day Thursday and Friday. Sign up near Entrance A for session times.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Open Spaces

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: This year we have a dedicated hotel room near the conference for people who need someplace for prayer time, or a quiet place to handle some personal things (breast feeding, etc). Not for office/work duties. Check in at the reg booth for the room key.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Prayer & Quiet Room

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
60 minutes, ten takeaways for making solid functional User Interface tests of web applications. In this session we’ll quickly cover the fundamentals of how automated web functional tests work, then dive into practical solutions you’ll be able use on a daily basis. You’ll see how to create maintainable tests using the Page Object Pattern, handle complex asynchronous (timing!) situations, and deal with common controls like complex grids, trees, calendars, and a number of other “interesting” automation scenarios.
You’ll leave this session armed with knowledge you can immediately apply to make your automated functional tests faster, more maintainable, and easier to write!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Ten Practical Tips for Automated Testing of Web Applications

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: When people hear the term user experience (UX), many automatically assume it’s a thing for only designers to understand. That couldn’t be further from the truth. Throughout the development of a product – be it an application or a website, it is important to keep the end users in mind. In the beginning, identify the target users and bond with them. Empathy for the end user goes a long way in development, as this talk will show. Interviewing, personas, usability testing, and refactoring are some of the tools that developers can wield while crafting solutions. “The UX Toolbelt for Developers” will show developers how to take advantage of these UX concepts to become better developers.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The UX Toolbelt for Developers

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
JavaScript fails in many ways. Perhaps an asset failed to load, maybe AJAX requests came back in a different order, or maybe the user installed some intrusive Ask Toolbar in their browser. Whatever the reason, too often the only clue is:
"TypeError: e is undefined, scripts.js, line 1"
Let's put an end to that. Let's find and fix the errors. This talk will show how the [object Error] works in old and modern browsers, how stack traces are created and formatted, and tricks to get better insight from errors. Let's explore how to get better context from errors and make the web a better place.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Traces of Errors: Getting A Better JavaScript Stack Trace

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Animal. Vegetable. Mineral. Machine. All these are part of the Internet of Things (IoT), which is a buzzword often discussed as of late, but is not a new concept. Many vendors are entering the race to provide a turnkey solution from the devices to the middleware to the analytics; one of which is Microsoft with their Azure IoT services. In this session, you will gain an understanding of the Microsoft Azure IoT services, how they work together, and if they might be a fit for you and your things. We’ll explore (and demo) device connectivity, IoT services interactions, and analytics and visualization. You will also leave with tips and tricks gained from working with the several of the IoT services over the course of the last year.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: You Won't Believe What Microsoft is Doing with Industrial Things on the Internet

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: The 2.0.1.5 scavenger hunt is on! Go to Hangoutz to pick up the clue sheet and roam the conference to find the answers. Do not be in a hurry as this is NOT a race. Not only do you have all day Thursday, but half the day on Friday to complete your quest! When you are done return to Hangoutz to have your answers checked and receive a sticker good towards a second ticket to distribute at the raffle.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: KidzMash: Scavenger Hunt (Part 1)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: This session features two things which most kids love: Computers and bouncing! Based on a real curriculum developed for UK primary schools, we will act out a variety of sorting algorithms by jumping from one square to another and comparing numbers when kids “collide.” This activity is accessible to any kid who knows how to take turns and compare two small numbers, but will also be interesting to older children and even adults. Much of the fun, of course, comes from the physical movement and interactions, but there is also considerable depth of knowledge available to those who are ready for it.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Big-O Hopscotch

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Elephants (named "Hadoop" after a toy), bees and hives, pigs, ELKs, rabbits and one ZooKeeper. You can find them in a zoo, or you are just a software developer trying to make sense out of data using technologies with weird names.
This session will be a guided tour of the BigData kingdom. We will explore various challenges one has to face when handling large volumes of data, and learn about various tools with funny names which were built to help in the process.
Equipped with real-world examples and use-cases, by the end of this session BigData should stop being a buzzword to you.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: A guided tour of the BigData technologies zoo

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Over the last year, many Automotive companies have released SDKs and APIs and Google have announced Automotive Android that finally allow Android developers to create their own mobile automotive apps that expand the boundaries of the automotive dashboard far beyond the physical car.
In this class, you'll learn how to create apps for this new and relatively overlooked commercial opportunity for mobile developers. We'll also build a couple of sample apps that focus on how communicate with Ford's Sync and GM's Remote APIs .
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Automotive Android

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: The internet of things revolution is coming. Are you ready for the onslaught of smart devices that is right around the corner? As developers, the more important question is, are you ready to be a part of contributing to the internet of things? The barrier to entry is now lower than ever - the Tessel board from Technical Machine (tessel.io) allows you to control hardware with JavaScript running in node.js on the embedded chip! Yeah - JavaScript. In this session, I'll give you an overview of the Tessel board and many of the modules available to build the next generation of smart devices. You'll be surprised how easy it is.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Building the Internet of Things... with JavaScript?

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Tired of callback hell and fighting with the event loop? Node.js is a popular choice for building real-time applications, but it comes with some serious drawbacks. Elixir, a new functional language targeting the Erlang VM, promises to combine the stability and scalability of Erlang with the expressiveness of Ruby. In this session, two implementations of the same real-time application will be compared: one written in Node.js and one written in Elixir. You will learn how Node and Elixir solve the same problems in very different ways, and see how Elixir enables massive concurrency and fault tolerance with code that is callback-free, concise, testable, and easy to reason about.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Callback-free concurrency: Elixir vs. Node

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
