Recognize the benefits of using a living pattern library and rapid prototyping to increase communication and collaboration between designers and developers. In this session we will review a case study from an enterprise-level development group traditionally staffed with 60+ developers and no designers and how they were able to implement a pattern library and rapid prototyping framework into their design and development process. In this session we will discuss:
• recognizing patterns • modular pattern creation • how patterns can be combined to be used during rapid prototyping • developing a consistent language that can be used between designers and developers
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Fostering Collaboration with Pattern Libraries and Rapid Prototyping

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: This session provides an introduction to building native Android apps using Android Studio. Topics are covered from the perspective of someone with .NET experience but are appropriate for anyone looking to get into the mobile space. We will begin by learning what Android has to offer and then build our first small, but functional application.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: From Visual Studio to Android Studio

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Wouldn’t it be nice if the simple action of checking in your latest changes into source control triggered an official build? Wouldn’t it be even better if, upon a successful build, the latest executables were automatically deployed to your test bed without you lifting a finger? If you’re not lucky enough to be deploying to a cloud platform that provides such functionality out of the box, automating your process might seem daunting. In this session, Danielle will demonstrate how you can leverage tools such as TeamCity and Octopus Deploy to automate your builds and deployments. You’ll be introduced to a variety of options you can use to customize the process in order to meet your particular requirements. Along the way, you’ll learn about some neat productivity features you may wish to leverage as well as some pitfalls you would do well to avoid.
You’ll leave this session with the knowledge of how to automate your own builds and deployments and how to extend that automation chain so you can reach the next level. Test automation, anyone?
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: From Zero to Full Deployment Automation in 60 Minutes

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
In May 2014, the Chicago Council on Global Affairs met in Washington, D.C. and predicted a perfect storm. On the one hand there is a demand for food from an ever growing population, whilst on the other, changes to the climate system are bringing storms, floods and heat waves which are diminishing crop yields.
In this session we'll take a code heavy (C#) look at what data science can do to help maximize crop yields, at every level, from sowing to harvest; including the interesting question of, "can we monitor crop health from space?" (hint: yes we can and it's very cool [grin]). So come along to this session and find out how data scientists are helping to save the world from the comfort of their offices.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: How to Save the World Without Wearing Your Underpants on the Outside

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Securing your websites and services using HTTPS has never been more important, or more complicated. In this talk, a former browser Security Program Manager covers the best practices for using HTTPS today.
Topics covered in this session include ciphers and hash algorithms, forward secrecy, handshakes and protocols, and new browser features like HSTS and PKP. Explore how attackers circumvent HTTPS, and what you can do to help protect your visitors and customers safe from snoops and bad guys.
Secure all the things!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: HTTPS in 2015

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
You've been using jQuery for years. You've got a well-worn handful of plugins and libraries you pull off the shelf to solve common problems. (Or you know how to Google for a new one when you need it.) Maybe you're even into MVC (Angular, Backbone, Knockout, etc.) or use RequireJS.
But do you really know JavaScript? Have you ever read through some of that third-party code? Do you understand "this"? What's an IIFE? What does "use strict" do? How do you use Promises?
Come to a deeper understanding of these topics - and more - and you too can level up your JavaScript!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Level Up Your JavaScript

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: This session will educate the user on how to use the Parse.com user service in their own iOS application. The first step in using Parse will be to create a login screen that will allow the user to register. Once registered and logged in, Parse will track some analytics on the frequency of the screens being used. A GitHub repository will be available for future reference of both Objective-C and Swift code bases.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Locking Out the Abominable Snowman in iOS

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Your cyclomatic complexity is through the roof. Your application is in danger of flunking out of Code Climate. Rubocop has issued a warrant for your arrest, and there's even whispered talk of declaring bankruptcy on your technical debt. You know that a serious refactoring is needed, but you can't take time out to mount a concerted attack on complexity. How do you break a major refactoring down into manageeable pieces? Do you know where in your tangled codebase to start? This talk will explore a small number of simple, practical tools and techniques useful in identifying problem areas, targeting your refactoring, and most importantly, measuring the results of your efforts.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Refactoring in Ruby: Finding the Right Job for the Tool

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: It is an amazing time to be a C# developer! For the past several years, the C# team has been focused on rebuilding the compilers and editing experiences as part of Project Roslyn. That work has finally come to fruition and is paving the way for C# to continue evolving for many years to come. Come see what all of the buzz is about. Explore new C# 6 language features, tour the new C# editing experience, harness the power of the Roslyn APIs, and dig into the source of the C# compiler itself. This is a session that you won’t want to miss!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The Future of C# is Now!

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Twelve Factor apps are built for agility and rapid deployment. They enable continuous delivery and reduce the time and cost for new developers to join a project. At the same time, they are architected to exploit the principles of modern cloud platforms while permitting maximum portability between them. Finally, they can scale up without significant changes to tooling, architecture or development practices.
In this talk, you’ll learn the principles and best practices espoused by the Twelve Factor app. We’ll discuss how to structure your code, manage dependencies, store configuration, run admin tasks, capture log files, and more. You’ll learn how modern Java deployments can benefit from adopting these principles, and why they fit nicely within the cloud.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The Twelve Factor App: Best Practices for JVM Deployment

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Do you have a job that's exciting? A job that you can't wait to get out of bed and contribute to? A team that you respect and enjoy working with? A management structure that makes great data-based decisions and a process that you feel really works?
If so, this talk is not for you.
If you feel trapped in a job that doesn't make you happy, this session will highlight key organizational antipatterns that signal things aren't going to get better. Be warned, however. You may leave this session with the motivation to change your life for the better and truly embrace happiness in newfound employment!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: You Need to Quit Your Job

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Too often does good UX design fall prey to “conventional wisdom” and an app or website is hijacked by stakeholders way too eager to believe theoretical nonsense, without any credible proof or even their own relevant experience. In this session, we will explore some of the more common pitfalls of UX mythology, from the legendary Adventures Beyond the Page Fold, to The 3 Clicks of Destiny, to The Faceted Navigation of Doom and more! We’ll look at each in turn and determine if each holds true or can be labeled as busted. There will be audience participation and prizes including the latest season of Myth Busters and a copy of Steve Krug’s, Rocket Surgery Made Easy. Armed with the truth, you will be able to reliably defend against the onslaught of poor UX, perpetrated by design-by-committee, and reach true UX harmony.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Adventures Beyond the Page Fold - Exploring UX Mythology

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Ever want to know how computers think? In this session attendees will learn the foundations of artificial intelligence through a collaborative discussion centered around the creation of an intelligent game. Attendees will also learn how to use advanced search techniques to solve complex problems using specialized heuristics. In short, attendees will understand how to make intelligent programs by learning how to pose an AI problem in order to maximize desired outcomes.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: An Introduction to Artificial Intelligence

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
In recent years, most Rails developers have usually used go-to services for going from git push to code being on production. As developers and operations staff we sometimes find ourselves with infrastructure and code bases growing under our feet and in our sleep and sometimes managed services stop meeting the needs of a business or project.
Once your business grows to the point where you have dedicated Sales, QA, and Growth departments, how do you manage to keep all the environments for everyone in check? When your bundling and asset compilation takes 30 minutes, how do you get hot fixes out in any reasonable amount of time? When your dev staff is distributed, how can you ensure everyone has access to the proper environment, and more importantly, that they don't have potentially destructive powers in places they shouldn't?
We've struggled with each of these questions, and after a lot of trial and error, ended up on a Docker based build and deploy system that accelerated our build times, time through CI, QA deploys, and general time to production with little to no downtime. We've also been able to deploy the same applications for demo use offline, quickly scale applications in the case of emergency, provide developer safe security, and a whole lot more
In this talk we'll talk about Rails-specific practices for building your app into a Docker image and what benefits you get immediately from that alone. Then we'll talk about how you can use that image through the rest of your dev process cycle to get the ease of use of a managed service with the freedom to use your container as you please.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Business Scale Rails with Docker

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Composition is powerful. Consider any artistic endeavor; any style of music, art, photography, etc. Creativity thrives on composition. The bringing together of various elements into a complementary whole. Carefully selected, simple pieces assembled with skill and insight can yield breathtaking complexity and beauty.
Yet composition s not widely used as a paradigm in creating software today. While it sounds nice in theory to write small, simple, and correct pieces of code and then plug them together, there is little in the way of practical examples to show how it's done. With practice, designing for composition can become second nature.
This talk will use the problem of writing a Clojure-to-C compiler as an example. A full explanation of the process, with code, will demonstrate how to accomplish this in Clojure while the concepts will be applicable to any functional programming language.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Composing a Compiler

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Every application we build is subject to attack. Every data item we store is subject to theft. And with most everything delivered by mobile and the Web, traditional network security devices cannot protect our code. This session presents three case studies in developing defensible applications; including code hardening, security logging, user stories for security operations, and embedding security throughout the development life cycle. We will examine each case from the perspective of technology, secure practices, security culture, and maturity model. Attendees will come away with practical guidance for improving their development processes and defending their applications. Our code will be attacked. Let’s be ready.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Defensible application architecture

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Facebook and OK Cupid have recently been under public scrutiny for the experiments they run on their users. The truth is every web site of a considerable enough scale experiments on their users. Whether it's searching for just the right shade of blue for the "Buy!" button or trying out a new algorithm to perfect the news feed, these are psychological experiments and the user is the subject.
In this talk, you'll be introduced to the basics of solid, overlapping, multivariate testing as well as a simple tool for enabling those experiments. This will enable you to perform more, better, safer experimentation. This talk will also include a healthy discussion on the ethics of experimentation to help steer you away from any possible controversy.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Ethics and Effective A/B Testing

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: You have been writing C# for years, and are happy with it - so why bother with F#? This talk will compare and contrast F# and C# with live coding examples, illustrating why F# is an awesome language, where it shines, and how it fits. So if you are open to the idea that C# might not be the one and only solution to all your coding problems, or if you are simply tired of null reference exceptions, come check out what F# has to offer, and how it beautifully complements C#!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: F# for the C# Developer

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: We are in the era of the Maker. Never before has DIY-type hardware been so accessible and affordable. The plethora of devices and sensors at our fingertips is staggering, giving us the power to bring our ideas to fruition. Microsoft recently unveiled their Windows on Devices developer program that brings a small Windows OS to a small device, in this case the Intel Galileo. The first preview enables developers to use Visual Studio to program and execute Arduino sketches on the Galileo. This session will provide an overview of the developer program, how to get started with Windows on the Galileo as well as a demonstration of a couple of projects.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Galileo Magnifico! IoT with Windows on Devices

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Tired of job boards and recruiter spam? There’s a better way to manage your career growth. Networking is something that doesn’t come naturally to most people, but it’s a tool that everyone should have in their tool belt. In this talk, you’ll learn tips for growing your professional network online and offline. You’ll also learn strategies for intentionally fostering relationships. A good network means fewer strangers, more free lunches, and a better path to finding your next opportunity.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: It’s OK to Talk to Strangers

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
As our industry matures there is an increasing demand for high-throughput, low-latency systems heavily utilizing event-driven programming and asynchronous processing. This trend is rapidly converging on the somewhat well established but so-far not well understood term "Reactive".
This session explores how Java EE as a whole aligns with this movement via features and APIs like JMS, MDB, EJB @Asynchronous, JAX-RS/Servlet async, CDI events, Java EE concurrency utilities and so on. We will also see how these robust facilities can be made digestible even in the most complex cases for mere mortal developers through Java SE 8 Lambdas and Completable Futures.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Reactive Java EE - Let Me Count the Ways!

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Modern web developers are drowning in a sea of div tags and JavaScript libraries. Our markup isn’t semantic. And there’s no standard for creating components that can be shared across projects. But there’s great news: Web components are coming to the rescue, and will dramatically redefine the way web apps are built. Learn how to create rich, powerful, and reusable components using tools you've already mastered: HTML5, JavaScript, and CSS. Explore the mysterious Shadow DOM and learn how it encapsulates components from manipulation by the outside world. And review the beauty and simplicity of injecting dependencies via HTML imports. These technologies are cutting-edge, but this session discusses how to begin leveraging their power to create reusable components that run in modern browsers, today!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The Dawn of the Reusable Web: Diving into Web Components

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: You know you have to have a great experience when you develop your Windows Phone 8 applications right? The greatest experience you can give your users is around their data. There are ways to improve your Windows Phone 8 application and Chris Woodruff will teach you how to get data quickly, save it with validation, save it locally and many, many more tricks. Come see why you should know the tricks of the trade before developing that killer Windows Phone 8 app. You will be a Data Experience expert when you leave the room after this session.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The Top Reasons You Need to Learn about Data in Your Windows Phone App

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: “I do not see the countries and peoples of Africa as a world apart; I see Africa as a fundamental part of our interconnected world”, President Barak Obama at US – Africa Summit in August, 2014. What he said here applies to the IT world as well. Companies and IT workers can’t afford to ignore what is going on in Africa. There are over 50 countries that make up Africa and this is a growing segment in terms of IT workers and market. A recent report by CNN stated that six African countries make up some of the world's fastest developing economies. Many of these countries have begun to position themselves as being IT havens for education, innovation, and entrepreneurship. From m-pesa to mHealth and the Kigali kLab to the Nairobi iHub, come and learn about some of the emerging IT trends that are being developed in and for Africa and how you can help inspire a new generation of young African IT women and men to obtain new heights.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: You may be at the Kalahari, but IT ain’t nothing like the real thing: The state of Information Technology in Africa

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: If someone you know gets sick or hurt, do you know what to do? This can be a scary time, but there's a lot that kids can do to provide care for friends and loved ones when they need it the most. Kids will leave this highly-interactive session with a solid foundation of what to do when emergency strikes.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: First Aid and Safety for Kidz

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Why should the parents have to have all the fun programming? Bring your little ones, and let them experience some of the fun and excitement of programming. Your little ones can experience the joy of being in Control of Mom or Dad.
Little Ones: Control your parents. Watch your parent execute commands such as step, swim, splash, fall. Make them power your inner tube, and go in the direction you want.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Kidz-In-Control, Water-park Edition (2)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Thursday Lunch
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Lunch

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
AngularJS empowers developers by providing the means to rapidly create rich user experiences, but its API is massive and you're busy. This session teaches the 5 concepts that you need to get productive in Angular, fast: ng-controller, ng-repeat, ng-model, ng-click, and filter. You'll then see how they're used together by exploring realistic and approachable code examples.
Attendees will walk out of this session with the tools needed to ship engaging, interactive, websites.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Angular's Missing Guide: Build Anything With These 5 Concepts

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Do you wish you could use OSX for ASP.NET development? Interested in exploring the .NET web frameworks, but are adverse to installing Windows and Visual Studio? Do you judge Mono as a less-than-ideal port of the .NET framework? Everything has changed: ASP.NET isn’t just for Windows, anymore. Learn how ASP.NET has broken free from Windows and has turned into a cross-platform, OS-agnostic framework. Develop ASP.NET applications on your OS, with your editor, in your way. No more compromises, no VMs, no workarounds: ASP.NET is coming to an OSX near you.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: ASP.NET is Coming to an OSX Near You

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Building web applications so that they are accessible to people with disabilities is easy. Yet many web developers don't spend the extra time to do it right. It is estimated that as many as one in five people have some sort of disability or impairment. Regardless of the purpose of the application this is essential to consider.
This session will include an in-depth discussion of web accessibility guidelines and standards following the WCAG 2.0 specification. It will also focus on a how-to for actually implementing these guidelines and building them into the UI of any web-based application. The web developer that is already skilled in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, will learn practical coding techniques to make their applications accessible to all.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Building with Web Accessibility in Mind

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Discover Swift, the new programming language from Apple. By examining and modifying a real iOS app, learn how it compares and contrasts with more established languages like JavaScript, C#, Python, and Objective-C. Begin the journey towards mastering Swift; seize on its possibilities and avoid its pitfalls.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Coming up to speed on Swift

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: This intermediate level session will help you get more out of debugging with Xcode. It will start with the basics, like logging, breakpoints and variables, and move to more advanced topics like conditional breakpoints, watching memory and location debugging.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Debugging with Xcode

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: DevOps is a lot of things. It’s also not a lot of things, and the differences can lead to confusion and incorrect assumptions. DevOps is related to Agile, but it’s not the same thing as Agile. It needs tools, but the tools are just a part of the story. DevOps is a cultural shift, a methodology, an operational philosophy, and a metaphor for software delivery. It’s only about five years old, so it’s still toddling around development teams, management meetings, and executive boardrooms, attracting attention with every conversation. The DevOps meme is about to go hype-rsonic, as Agile did about ten years ago. When that happens, you’ll want to have a good idea what it is, what is isn’t, and why you and your company should care. This presentation will cut through the hype and boil DevOps down to its bare essentials. I’ll talk about what DevOps is and the value it offers. I’ll dispel a few common myths, and demonstrate resources for supporting DevOps Transformation in your organization. DevOps means different things to different people, so we’ll talk about how to communicate DevOps concepts to various enterprise stakeholders. When we’re done, you’ll be empowered to go out into the world and talk about DevOps, and maybe even help make it happen at your company.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: DevOps: What it is, What it Isn't, and Why Coders Should Care

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
You keep hearing about this Elixir thing. "It's functional, meta-programmable, concurrent, and AWESOME!" they exclaim. I don't know who *they* are, but they're totally right.
As a long-time Rubyist, I've come to believe that Elixir has been artisianally crafted to suit the Rubyist's discriminating taste. We'll examine how Elixir's features and philosophy make it uniquely suited to complement the Rubyist's toolbelt, and how it might just change the way you think about solving problems.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Elixir is for Rubyists

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: I will be presenting on my personal experience integrating existing Grails applications with AngularJS. Most Grails developers rely on GSPs to display structured data, however, this can be cumbersome. With the introduction of AngularJS, a powerful client MVC platform, the client's browser can help provide a dynamic and light UI experience. We will explore how Angular directives, controllers and services can integrate with Grails controllers, web sockets and more. We will ensure functionality and code quality throughout the stack using Jasmine, Spock and CucumberJs tests.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Grails and AngularJS, bridging the gap

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Invariants, locking, mutexes, critical sections, monitors, barriers, race conditions, non-deterministic, memory coherence, consistency models, etc. "Multithreading is hard", hard to do correctly and easy to do incorrectly. "Correctly" is almost always application-specific and usually caveated with "it depends". It's hard to define specific rules or practices that work in all circumstances. This session takes a different point of view on things and shows you specific ways to do things "wrong" with regard to multi-thread. This session will detail some of the common primitives and techniques use in multi-threading, but used in the wrong ways. Why they are wrong and alternatives will be covered. Topics like Sleep, DoEvents, volatile, lock, interlocked, thread priority, non-shared data, etc. will be covered.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: How *Not* to Write Concurrent Code

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: What makes an immersive Virtual Reality experience? While that really is the ultimate question, other questions may include: how do I integrate the Oculus Rift into my existing game? Do I need to change any settings? What about my UI? How can I make sure my friend’s don’t puke? Join Nathalie for this session to learn about integrating the Oculus Rift into your Unity game, and Virtual Reality design principles.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Making Awesome with Oculus Rift

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Rewriting your Master Testing Strategy is in order when you look to tackle your first mobile initiative. This includes getting your test environments ready for testing. Often test environments have been on closed internal networks that are not accessible from the internet. Delivering and testing a mobile application on a 3G or 4G network changes all that. Coming up with a supported platform strategy is also paramount to success. One needs to take network speed, device features, screen size and resolution as well as multi-tasking life-cycles into effect when testing. QA testers will need to become familiar on how to service the devices they test with as well. Additionally the team will need to incorporate field testing prior to delivery. This presentation will organize the challenges a modern QA team has to contend with, and make some strong suggestions on how to craft a respectable Mobile Test Strategy.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Take Your QA Team Out - Mobile Testing Strategies Everyone Should Know About

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Smart businesses come up with a mission, vision, and values that define the way that they do business and help them focus for success. So why don't we apply the same ideas to our own lives and careers? I'll go over ten steps that you can take to run your career like a business, take control of your life, and help you work towards a successful life and career on your terms.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The Business of You - 10 Steps for Running Your Career Like a Business

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Traditional databases have relied on large servers, fast networks, and expansive storage to solve the problem of scale. In the last couple years, as “cloud” has become less of a buzzword, and more of a practical solution, traditional database architecture has presented a barrier to implementing medium to large scale applications. While the big players (Microsoft and Oracle) are beginning to find ways to adapt to the needs of a cloud architecture, they are being outpaced by a new crop of databases. These databases are designed from the ground up to solve the problem of cloud scale. This session focuses on the theory behind database distribution, starting with a definition of the problem, and ending with the varying solutions that a number of the front-runners have implemented. While it has yet to be determined which approach will win, this session will prepare the audience to make intelligent decisions about which solution works best for their particular problem domain in the present and in the future.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The Silver Lining: A Deep Dive into the Architecture of Distributed Databases

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Think your data is safe? Don't be so sure. While crypto plays a role in nearly every system of any complexity, it’s often flawed due to common misunderstandings of how it should be implemented. This presentation discusses common mistakes seen in the wild, such as using the wrong block mode, misusing IVs, insecure password storage, poor key generation, and others. While this may sound like gibberish to the uninitiated, these issues, and how to tackle them will be clearly explained. Useful, practical advice for designing secure systems will be given along the way, making it easier to catch these mistakes before they make it to production - saving time, and protecting companies and users alike.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: What you don’t know about crypto can hurt you!

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: In this session we will go over parts of a video game system, ratings system for games, and balancing video games with chores and other activities. Of course, we will also play games together, including teaching each other how to play new games, and a mini-tournament. This session will cover the requirements to complete the Cub Scouts Computers Belt Loop and Pin. There may be additional effort needed after the session to fulfill the requirements.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: All About Video Games!

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
After using TDD for over 10 years to build software, I've seen and used every anti-pattern in the book. From brittle tests, over-mocked tests and everything in between.
Tests are supposed to improve maintainability, drive design decision and uncover code smells. Tests can do all these things, but only if we’re writing good tests. In this session, we’ll cover eight simple rules for writing good tests, from what to embrace and what to avoid. Nothing is sacred in this session, as I’ll cover all the ways I’ve failed with testing and where I find success in testing today.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: 8 Simple TDD Rules

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: There's no reason why Agile practices and Android can't go hand in hand. In this class, learn how to add TDD (test driven development or unit tests) to your next Android project. Thankfully, you no longer have to rely on Google's Unit3 testing framework. The class begins with a look at what tools are available for Unit Testing, Mocking and Code Coverage from ActivityInstrumentationTestCase2 (jUnit3), Roboelectric (jUnit4) to Mockito and Dagger. We'll also create a sample app using Roboelectric and Dagger to show best practices for creating a Test Driven Environment.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Android TDD

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: You can't go to a Ruby conference lately without someone banging on about concurrency and thread safety. You're a smart Rubyist, but... you don't get it. You understand the basic idea, you nod along, but once they get into the jargon, what does it all mean? How does it apply to you, and what is it, exactly? This talk will answer those questions, by engaging in a basic primer on concurrency in Ruby, a discussion of actual examples of how it works, and provide you with answers that will leave you nodding in agreement, rather than nodding off.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Concurrency for !Dummies (Who Don't Get It (...Yet))

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
This is an introductory session to Cross-Platform Mobile Development using C# with Xamarin's tools. We will cover the basics of cross-platform mobile development with Xamarin, including a discussion of what you CAN and CAN'T do, the business case for using Xamarin instead of native development, and the different approaches to code-sharing that Xamarin provides.
If you're a .NET developer interested in breaking into Mobile, or have heard of Xamarin but want to know if it's really as good as it sounds, this is the session for you.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Cross-Platform Mobile Development with C#

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
CSS is hard. It’s a simple language, but getting it right and avoiding specificity hell can be a challenge if you don’t have the right framework to back you up. Especially in large scaling projects, you might start adding ID selectors here and !important properties there and the next thing you know you’ve backed yourself into a corner where even the smallest of UI changes will take hours to work out. Ew.
Or how about this? Ever jump into a project and find that even the slightest markup change results in broken JavaScript AND sometimes even broken backend feature tests?! WTF. Ew.
This talk will look at how taking a modular, object-oriented approach to CSS can turn frontend woes into frontend wins. We’ll examine modern CSS approaches like OOCSS, SMACSS, and BEM and demonstrate how they will help to not only decouple your CSS styles and reduce specificity conflicts, but how they will also help to decouple your CSS and HTML from your JavaScript and feature specs.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Decoupling the Frontend through Modular CSS

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: ECMAScript most famous dialect is JavaScript, and the coming version is ECMAScript 6 (ES6). Browsers already started supporting some of its features. JS programmers need to start learning about the coming changes. The presentation will show some of ES6 most useful features like classes, block scope, collections, proxies, arrow functions, iterators, generators, comprehensions, and modules. We will concentrate on the practical aspects of the changes. The session will be interactive, includes many code examples, and will encourage audience participation. By the end of the presentation, participants will know when and how to use ES6 in their own projects.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: ECMAScript 6 Now

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Where do good ideas come from and how do we track them? Can we prioritize them and who gets to work on which idea?
Engineering teams obsess over how we manage the work of today and provide valuable feedback on the development process: Why are we building this feature? When will that feature be completed? What portions of the code changed in order to support this feature? These same teams rarely focus on the big ideas of tomorrow, even though in this information age most of what a company will do tomorrow is led by engineering.
Innovation happens best with small teams and structure, so like automated testing and builds, let's apply the same systemization to improvements and ideas so that the very best potential innovations are always at the forefront, and the best people are able to work on them at any point in time.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Engineering Innovation

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Now that you have made the choice to use gradle, what’s next? In this session, you will learn how turn the build from something everyone tries to avoid intro something you can actually love. Find out about strategies for making build scripts that are actually maintainable as well as some of the cooler advanced features you should be aware of and could be making use of starting today. What’s new in Gradle 2? What are some of the leaders in the industry doing with gradle? Finally learn how gradle fits nicely in your continuous delivery pipeline.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Getting Good at Gradle

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: In this session, 25 years of experience in hiring top talent in the Silicon Valley, all over the USA, Europe, Dubai and Australia will be shared to better understand what to concentrate on for success in an industry that changes so often. Are you a student or new to the industry? come to this session. Are you an experienced Developer that is locked in one area of technology and want to be involved with other technologies but don't know which one? come to this session. Want to know how to handle a technical interview? come to this session Finally, want to know the secret of success in the consulting business, this session will be your most valuable session at Codemash.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: How to get a job in the Software Business?

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Many companies mistakenly view Agile as nothing more than a process or methodology that will solve their development woes and permit them to launch better software faster. In this presentation Bermon will focus on sharing Agile as a way to think about how to software could be created and ways user experience can be integrated. UX practitioners, designers, and developers are all welcome.
Attendees will discover:
• a better definition of User Experience and the disciplines involved • a brief explanation of Agile • difficulties that exist when integrating user experience and Agile • ways to improve integrating user experience in an Agile setting
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Integrating User Experience and Agile

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: We all want to protect data that is entrusted to us. Whether we are required to protect sensitive information because of regulations or just to keep the trust of our users a good understanding of encryption is essential. In this session we will work through common data encryption scenarios and use encryption techniques to ensure that your data stays protected. We will also review common mistakes when using encryption and learn how to avoid them. Additionally, we will discuss techniques to guard against tampering and how to maintain the security of our data over the long term.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Keeping Secrets: Using Encryption Effectively

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
In the near future, everything will be connected: cities, enterprises, human beings, and more. This reality is just over the horizon, and it brings one of the largest challenges in building distributed systems. Today, developers often look to RESTful Web APIs to solve these problems. Are current trends in API design really prepared to handle the demands of the future? What’s missing from the equation?
In this session, you’ll learn new patterns for modeling Web APIs using state machines, hypermedia, and reactive streams to meet tomorrow’s challenges and make a solid attempt at standing the test of time.
Learn what you can do to make your API servers more scalable and resilient while allowing API clients to be event-driven and responsive. A real-world example will be given of how these concepts were used to build Zetta, an open source platform for the Internet of Things.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Reactive Hypermedia: the API Design of Tomorrow

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: At long last, Microsoft speaks NoSQL. Redmond’s long awaited answer to the likes of MongoDB and RavenDB is the (still-in-preview) Azure DocumentDB database-as-a-service. See how easy it is to create and configure a document database with the Azure Management Portal and immediately start to query its schema free data with familiar semantics that are common to relational database systems. In this session we'll also take some time to look at some of DocumentDB's strengths/limitations, along with what scenarios make a good fit for using this product and how DocumentDB stacks up against its competitors.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The Empire Strikes Back; Azure DocumentDB

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Open source tools. We all use them. Whether it's an entire toolkit, a framework that meets some specific needs, or a simple custom control from NuGet, CodePlex, or CodeProject, it is hard to ignore the opportunity to improve the rate of development while learning new things from open source projects. But what does "open source" truly mean? Especially when working in a professional or corporate environment, what are our rights and limitations as open source consumers to use, modify, and redistribute these tools? Often that depends upon the authors' own decisions regarding project licensing. In this one-hour session, we will review a few of the core principals of open-source development and consumption, comparing and contrasting some of the more popular licenses in use today. We will then discuss both how to use the open source works of others and also how to properly license your own.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The Impact of Leveraging Open Source

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Performance matters. How fast your site loads -- not just on your development machine, but from your actual customers, across the globe -- has a direct impact on your visitors' happiness and conversion rate. Today's browsers provide several new cutting-edge performance APIs that can give you Real User Metrics (RUM) of your live site's performance. Whether you run a small blog or a top-1K site, monitoring and understanding your performance is the key to giving your visitors a better experience.
We will be discussing the NavigationTiming, ResourceTiming and UserTiming performance APIs, which are available in the majority of modern browsers. You'll walk away with a better understanding of what problem these APIs solve and how to start using them today. We’ll also go through both D.I.Y. and commercial options that utilize these APIs to help you better monitor and improve the performance of your websites.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Using Modern Browser APIs to Monitor and Improve the Performance of Your Web Applications

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: How we build software has so radically changed that it’s impacting the entire technology ecosystem (from students, to startups, to enterprises). This talk will explore some of the impact this having on innovation, and how Microsoft is supporting these communities to go even further.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Why Hack?

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
The Marshmallow Challenge is a remarkably fun and instructive design exercise that encourages teams to experience simple but profound lessons in collaboration, innovation and creativity.
The task is simple: in eighteen minutes, teams must build the tallest free-standing structure out of 20 sticks of spaghetti, one yard of tape, one yard of string, and one marshmallow. The marshmallow needs to be on top.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The Marshmallow Challenge

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Presented by Matt Kuznicki ] * Overview of the PDF format * Basic objects and object-oriented nature * Graphics and text primatives * Interactivity - and potential security concerns * Purpose: what is PDF great for, what's it not so good at * Great for: where predictable visual layout is desired; complex layouts * Digitally signed documents, legal documents * Reliable exchange across different people, across time and space * Not so good for: editing / changing * Difference between a document and a publication - some things you don’t want changing over time * PDF in the mobile world: why is mobile viewing difficult? * Vendors: OSS, commercial * Our tools and WebAPI
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: An Introduction to PDF

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
[Presented by Sebastian Holst, Chief Strategy Officer, PreEmptive Solutions] If you’re building a website or the next Angry Birds, this session is NOT for you. If you build applications for banking, manufacturing, healthcare, or other “real world” environments and have to balance every new and exciting innovation with existing security, privacy, and compliance obligations – as well as the obligation to keep your existing systems up and running – then you really need good application analytics – and this session is most definitely for you.
In just 45 minutes, we’ll break out use cases, requirements, and project management best practices for deploying an effective application analytics implementation – across on-premises and hybrid environments – across desktop PCs and the latest mobile devices. Attendees will leave with a self-assessment checklist and an organized set of tasks to bring true application analytics – insights into usage, behavior and quality – to the application stakeholders that need it most.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Application Analytics for The Rest of Us

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Presented by Bradley Holt] Mobile web apps shouldn't stop working when there's no network connection. Learn how to build cross-platform mobile web apps that work just as well offline as they do online. This talk will demonstrate how you can use HTML5 and PouchDB, an open source syncing JavaScript database that runs within a web browser, to provide a better, faster user experience, both offline and online. Learn how PouchDB synchronization can be used to replicate to and from a remote database, such as CouchDB or IBM Cloudant (a globally distributed data layer for web and mobile applications), whenever an Internet connection is available.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Build Offline-Enabled Apps with PouchDB

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Presented by Thom Valley] Get an introduction to all the new Datastax provided Apache Cassandra drivers (Python, Scala, C#, Java etc.), including new features and best practices.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Cassandra Development Using Your Favorite Language

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
[Presented by Sam Basu] It’s almost 2015 and it’s insane not to support every mobile platform to reach broadest user base. Let’s keep this simple:
X-Plat Hybrid Mobile development | Your Web Skills | Single codebase | HTML5/JS | Apache Cordova | Telerik AppBuilder | Choice of IDEs | Backend Services | Telerik Platform | End-to-End Mobile.
Join me as we explore the possibilities!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Cross-Platform Hybrid Mobile Development

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Presented by Joe Brach] Detroit's Tech Hub has expanded into a full city block including 6 buildings housing more than 100 of the nation’s most exciting, growing, digitally-focused businesses. Recognized as one of seven cities in the Google for Entrepreneurs national Tech Hub Network, Detroit is fast becoming one of the country’s preeminent destinations and environments for entrepreneurs to launch and grow their businesses, secure capital investment and tap into a highly talented and educational brainforce.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Detroit 2.0: The New Tech Hub

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
[Presented by Mike Folk] It doesn't take much thought to realize that technology is one of, if not the most important aspect of any company that wants to be in business tomorrow. With constant technological advances happening in the marketplace, companies must continuously evolve and update their technology or die. Because of this do-or-die scenario, the role of the technology leader has become critical to the success of the organization. While most companies have their own technology department, not every technology department has a strong leader. Those that do will survive. Those that don't...
And therein lies the rub. Companies are in constant search mode for progressive, visionary tech leaders. But the market is drying up. With virtually every company in the hunt for talent, there are just too many opportunities for these leaders to choose from.
This session will discuss the evolving market for tech leaders at all levels, dispel some old images of what makes a strong tech leader and share traits for identifying and retaining leadership within your organization.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Leadership in Technology

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
[Presented by Jonathan Baker, Brandon Zeeb and Andy Conley] As library collections shift from print materials to digital formats, and as the web enables ubiquitous and instantaneous discovery of information, library users expect to find and access materials online. It’s not enough to have pages “on the web”; library data must be “woven into the web” and integrated into the sites and services that library users frequent daily – Google, Wikipedia, social networks. When information about a library’s collection is locked up behind a specific web site (such as an OPAC), it is often exceedingly difficult for services, such as search engines, to that consume data. Information seekers need to be connected back to their local library resources from wherever they are on the web.
As a library cooperative, OCLC is at the forefront of linked data discussions and is leading the way in designing and implementing new approaches that re-envision, expose and share library data as entities that are part of the web. The release of data for bibliographic entities - WorldCat Works - will over time be joined by other key entities.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Linked Data and Semantic Web Development

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
[Presented by Michael Falanga] Abstract:
Today's web applications have a lot of concerns. In order to make applications more robust, JavaScript needs to be unit tested. In order to reduce page weight and load times, CSS and JS files should be concatenated and minified. To increase reliability across clients, they should not use cached versions of old CSS and JavaScript files.
In this talk, we will setup an ASP.Net MVC project that leverages the ASP.Net Web Optimization Framework and the grunt JavaScript task runner to create a front-end development environment that is both effective, productive, and easily integrated into your Continuous Integration server.
Bio:
With fifteen years of experience helping small businesses develop products to service their clients, Michael has learned effective practices for engaging the Whole Team to create high quality software. From product ownership to release planning to engineering best practices, Michael has led and contributed to all parts of the software development lifecycle.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Productive Tooling for Front-End Development

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
[Presented by Keith Rhodes] You have new tools like Jasmine, Selenium, Cucumber, Karma and Mocha. You integrate early and often with Jenkins, Travis and Bamboo. You do automated deployments, regression testing on pull requests and have code coverage metrics that would make your grandfather proud! You are an automation ninja but that accessibility thing is crimping your style. It doesn’t have to be that way. Come and learn how to integrate automated accessibility testing into all your modern tooling and restore the shine to your development workflow.
In this session Keith Rhodes, from Deque Systems, will demonstrate automated accessibility testing for iOS and web applications with tooling from Deque. Then Jason Karns from Test Double will talk usage scenarios for the various alternatives when integrating accessibility tooling into your development workflow.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Stop feeling guilty about your lack of accessibility testing – by automating it!

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
[Presented by Greg Jordan] In this talk, we’ll walk through the basics of coding with Swift, the latest iOS language for building apps, as well as review a demo social application. Social applications benefit from using graph/connected data structures, so we will also show how to integrate database-as-a-service with Swift through an open source library called Theo.
Attendees will learn:
- Setting up a new Swift Application - Basics of coding with Swift - Integrating a database-as-a-service provider with your app
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Swift kick in the Graph

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Presented by Jeff Yates] CareEvolution sponsored the NodeBots precompiler even though we are a Healthcare IT company. What do tiny robots have to do with Healthcare? It’s all about company culture. From manager-less emergent teams to pragmatic decision making, our organization innovates, supports, and works to fix the state of Healthcare in the US. Learn how we employ “Minimum Viable Process” to keep our customers and their patients happy and healthy, as well as ourselves.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: We’re Not All Robots! Hacking NodeBots, Healthcare, and the Workplace

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
[Presented by David Michels] Wearable technologies are no longer a thing of the future. They offer real-world value and many organizations are looking to solve their critical business problems utilizing these technologies. We will be discussing the technology at the core of many of these devices Bluetooth Low Energy - how it works and how you can use it. We will also review two client based proof of concepts which have been implemented using wearable tech. The functionality and technology to be reviewed is:
1. Using Google Glasses to reduce human error and provide real-time system updates in a warehouse environment. 2. Using Bluetooth Low Energy devices to login to industrial equipment. This system gives an extra layer of physical security ensuring the right person is accessing the equipment.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Wearable Tech in the Workplace

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Presented by Michael Grucella] When was the last time you hard-coded data? Databases have been around since the early days of computing. Architects spend time determining *which* database to use, not whether to build their own or not. Rule engines have existed for decades, yet they're relatively unknown. Developers waste millions of hours each year hard-coding logic that could be externalized, authored by business users or even developers themselves, and deployed to production in an instant. In this talk, Mike provides an overview of rule engines, where they provide great value...and where they don't.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Why are you still hard-coding business logic?

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Presented by Jesse Liberty] Xamarin Forms represent a radical departure for Xamarin development, allowing the creation of a UI that runs -- and looks — native on each platform. Thus, you can add a list to your form and be assured that it not only will run native but will appear 100% consistent with the look and feel of each of iOS, Android and Windows Phone. In this presentation Jesse Liberty will show you how to get started with Xamarin Forms and why they may be the future of mobile development.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Xamarin Forms and The Future of Mobile Application Development

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: While you won't really build an army, you will take command of a robot. Kids ages 7-10 are invited to come and learn how to program in a simple visual environment. There will be challenges to solve and obstacles to avoid. Can you learn enough to take over the world with your robot?
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Controlling Your Robot Army

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Our annual Women of CodeMash Photo will be taken at the grand staircase.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Women of CodeMash Photo

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: The general thinking is that when you create a new application, your data will be persisted into an RDBMS like SQL Server. But with the advent of NoSQL solutions, document databases, key-value stores and other options, do you really need an RDBMS for your application? In this session we’ll look at some alternatives to your persistence solution by looking at utilizing NoSQL solutions like Mongo, search services like Solr, key-value stores and other approaches to data persistence. By the end of this session, you’ll rethink how your applications will store data in the future.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Being RDBMS Free

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
In this world of ever increasing opportunities to purchase 'toys' classified as 'drones'... have you ever wanted to fly a drone? Have you ever asked yourself the question... should I buy a drone or build?
This presentation will discuss why the term 'drone' should be most generally referred to as... 'multi-rotor copter' and not UAV (unmanned autonomous vehicle) or drone.
This presentation will discuss the basics of how a multi-rotor works... the steps to build a multi-rotor... including details on flight controllers, frame selection, motors and props (including determining what type of multi-rotor will suite your purpose), speed controllers and batteries. There are a lot of variables... all of these details will be broken down, making the process of building your first copter a 'flight in the park'.
At the end... a flying multi-rotor copter will be air-worthy and demonstrated.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: BYOD : build your own drone... multi-rotor copter that is !

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: We spend much of our time collecting and analyzing data. That data is only useful if it can be displayed in a meaningful, understandable way. Yale professor Edward Tufte presented many ideas on how to effectively present data to an audience or end user. In this session, I will explain some of Tufte's most important guidelines about data visualization and how you can apply those guidelines to your own data. You will learn what to include, what to remove, and what to avoid in your charts, graphs, maps and other images that represent data.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Effective Data Visualization

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
F# is an incredibly versatile and expressive language and enables you to solve a wide array of problems succinctly and efficiently. This talk illustrates, with real-world examples, how the Gamesys social team uses F# to build the backend services that support around 1 million Daily Active Users (DAU) and 250 million daily requests across its social games on both mobile and web platforms.
Talk objectives:
- Demonstrate the use of F# to write clean, concise game logic as well as infrastructure code, the same techniques and concepts can be easily applied to other domains;
- Demonstrate how F# can help tackle recurring business problems of:
Efficiency Correctness Complexity Time to Market
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: F# in social gaming

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: You’ve seen Chrome extensions in the wild, maybe even installed a few into your browser — but what about writing your own? In this talk, you’ll learn the basics of Chrome extension development (from git init to publishing in the Web Store), how to avoid having your extension automatically disabled when performing upgrades, and some unexpected parts of Chrome you can hook into to take your extension to the next level.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Getting Started with Chrome Extensions: Tips and Tricks

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Ever wonder how software development rock stars got so successful? Get the most out of your hard work and experience by learning some proven ways to measure your accomplishments, establish a personal brand, and increase your value to employers.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: How to be a Six Figure Developer

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
The sea change in HTML5 is poised to shift the pendulum away from today's thin-client based server-side web frameworks like Struts 2 and JSF to JavaScript powered rich clients. With strong support for REST, WebSocket and JSON, Java EE is well positioned to adapt to this landscape.
In this heavily code driven session, we will show you how you can utilize today's most popular JavaScript rich client technologies like AngularJS, Backbone, Knockout and Ember to utilize the core strengths of Java EE using JAX-RS, JSR 356/WebSocket, JSON-P, CDI and Bean Validation.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Java EE 7 with JavaScript/HTML5 Rich Clients

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
A talk discussing what needs to occur in order to take your existing Android application and have it work well on Google's new Android TV platform. Topics discussed will focus on optimizing your apps for Remote Control, Game Pad, and Voice inputs. As well as experiences from taking an existing application developed for Google TV and Tablets and migrating it to work on Google's reference development device for Android TV.
We'll review the various design patterns, the android leanback library, and discuss when it may be beneficial to think outside of the guidelines, but not too far.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Migrating to Android TV

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: When it comes to mobile development, it can feel like "best practices" in software development have been left behind. Devs may be able to quickly launch flashy prototypes, but this approach won’t solve larger challenges often found in many organizations. "Best practices” in the web-application development world have taken years to reach where they are today. Now it’s time to progress these techniques into the mobile space, as well. This isn’t amateur hour anymore. This session will address some of those “gaps” by taking a look at technologies that expediently bridge the divide.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Mobile Craftsmanship: Technologies to elevate cross-platform native mobile development

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
What's that you say? You don't like working in JavaScript because you can't code like you want to with capital "O" Objects all over the place? Sure you can. More and more people are starting to realize how powerful this little language can be - start your re-education with this session and learn all about OOP in JS. First, we have to accept that while JavaScript may exhibit some characteristics of a functional language, it is really a multi-paradigm language with strong support for Object-Oriented Programming concepts.
This talk will give attendees a crash course in Object-Oriented JavaScript covering: * core OOP principles * the prototype object and constructors * member access types (public, private, & privileged) * prototypical inheritance * interfaces (mixins)
Developers will come out of this session ready to implement core OOP concepts in JavaScript, with knowledge of how inheritance in JavaScript differs from many of the other languages they know.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Object-Oriented JavaScript (yes, it really exists)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Mobile apps are a fixture in today's digital world. With the release of Apple's new Swift language, the barrier to entry to create iOS apps has been lowered and may increase the number of offerings in the App Store. Learn how to find vulnerabilities in today's apps, attack and manipulate them, and finally fix the issue. Explore common mobile vulnerabilities hands-on (or just follow along) through the new open-source, intentionally vulnerable Swift iOS application, Swift.nV (https://github.com/nVisium/Swift.nV).
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Practical iOS App Attack and Defense

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Sometimes a language just can’t express all the rules you want to enforce – or sometimes you want to break normal “best practices” in a very limited and controlled way. Now that Roslyn is open source, you *could* just change the language to fit your needs – but that’s an option which is likely to make you unpopular with you colleagues. Instead, in many cases you can let the compiler act in a perfectly normal way – but add extra rules on top, either while you're coding, as part of your normal build, or as tests alongside your regular unit tests.
This session reflects my experience of using Roslyn (in the Visual Studio 2015 Preview) to try to enforce rules within the Noda Time code base. There are highlights, lowlights, and much more that can come in the future. At the end of this session, you should have some idea of what you can do with Roslyn code diagnostics: what's easy, what's hard, and what's not quite working yet.
It's highly likely that there are better approaches to some of the problems I'm tackling - so if we're lucky, we may be able to arrange a follow-on Open Space session with members of the Roslyn team to find out what my code should look like...
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Roslyn in the Real World

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Ruby is known for Rails and the web. But, it's also the language behind Vagrant, Chef, and Puppet - three of the biggest drivers of the DevOps movement. Come see why this is a key skillset in the new operations.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Ruby -the language of DevOps

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Many developers decided to get into the software industry because of gaming. Many developers play games. Far fewer attempt making games. In this session, Chad Carter (who loves to play games and make games) will be showing how to get started using Unity. This 101 course will explain how the editor itself works and how Unity can be used out of the box with MonoDevelop or integrated to work with Visual Studio. Writing a game in Unity requires real coding and there will be plenty of coding examples. Fortunately, a lot of heavy lifting is done by the game engine. It has really never been easier to create a game. Using information from this session you will be able to jump right in and start creating your very own game that can be ran on all the major platforms. Unity 3D is free to create games for Windows, Windows 8, Windows Phone, Linux, Mac, iOS and Android. Take some time to drop by and learn something fun.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: See How Easily You Can Create a Cross-Platform 3D Game Using Unity

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
In this presentation, we’ll provide a practical walkthrough of the methods and technologies needed to analyze large data sets and test results. The presentation will be divided into several parts.
Part I -- Big Picture Here, we’ll focus on the big picture. What are the questions that we’re trying to answer? What data do we need to answer big questions?
Part II -- Analysis Platform We’ll focus on the creation of a data warehouse and the migration of transactional data into a format and platform appropriate for analysis. Here, we’ll talk about automation using Amazon’s S3 and Redshift products.
Part III -- Analysis Database Architecture and Queries In this step, we’ll discuss database architecture and query approach for analysis. We’ll introduce the idea of “dimensions” and “partitions,” which will be the central focus of our database structure.
Part IV -- Descriptive Analysis In Part IV, we’ll talk about descriptive analysis. How to efficiently explore data and generate reports using D3 and PrinceXML.
Part V -- Stats and Predictive Analysis In Part V, we’ll talk statistics and prescriptive analysis, transitioning from SQL to R as a stats engine to create models and evaluate probabilities.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The Analyst’s Cookbook: Practical Methods for Data Science using Redshift and R

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
From general programming to documentation to compiler innovations, women have been instrumental in advancing the computing industry. Let’s take a trip through the history of computing and meet some of the women who helped get our industry to where it is today.
Some of the inspiring women we’ll meet include Ada Byron (founder of Scientific Computing), Grace Murray Hopper (mother of COBOL), The ENIAC crew – Kay McNulty, Betty Jean Jennings, Betty Snyder, Marlyn Mescoff, Fran Bilas, and Ruth Lichterman, Adele Goldstine (ENIAC documenter), Frances Allen (First female to win the Turing award, known for her compiler optimizations), Mary Lou Jepsen (Founder and CTO of One Laptop Per Child), and Barbara Liskov (Liskov substitution principle).
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The History of Women in Tech

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: (100 min) (PG) Bring a beverage. Popcorn will be provided
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: KM Movie: The Lego Movie

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
What's does a mouse drag event have in common with an Array of numbers?
The answer to this question may surprise you: they are both collections. This key insight holds the key to dramatically simplifying asynchronous programming in JavaScript. In this talk you will learn how you can use the familiar JavaScript Array methods to create surprisingly expressive asynchronous programs. Using just a few functions, you will learn how to do the following: • Declaratively build complex events out of simple events (ex. drag n' drop) • Coordinate and sequence multiple Ajax requests • Reactively update UI's in response to data changes • Eliminate memory leaks caused by neglecting to unsubscribe from events • Gracefully propagate and handle asynchronous exception
In this talk we'll be exploring the Reactive Extensions (RxJS) library (http://github.com/reactive-extensions/RxJS), which allows us to treat events as collections. You'll learn about how Netflix uses Rx on the client and the server, allowing us to build end-to-end reactive systems. We'll also contrast Rx with Promises, another popular approach to building asynchronous programs in JavaScript.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Async JavaScript at Netflix

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
The modern world of concurrency can certainly be confusing! This talk is a gentle introduction to the many forms of concurrency. In this talk, you'll learn which types of concurrency are appropriate for which scenarios.
Most developers have heard of parallelism, so this talk starts with parallel computing, showcasing the Parallel class and Parallel LINQ (PLINQ).
The next stop is asynchronous code. Asynchronous code is a totally different kind of concurrency than parallel processing, and the async and await keywords enable maintainable asynchronous code in modern applications.
This talk will also introduce you to TPL Dataflow. A beautiful mix of parallel and asynchronous techniques, TPL Dataflow is a little-known but extremely powerful library.
The last technology covered is Reactive Extensions. This talk will cover the concepts behind Rx and the most useful operators. This session is entirely practical; the phrase "mathematical dual of IEnumerable" does not appear on any slides.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Asynchronous? Parallel? Reactive? Help!

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Now that you’ve seen how to take advantage of what’s new in C# as a consumer, come learn how to leverage the .NET Compiler Platform to transform your library into Code Aware Framework. This session will demonstrate how to help users of your library avoid common misuses of your API by implementing a user diagnostic which runs as part of the compilation process for anyone who references your NuGet package and is reported live in Visual Studio. Next we’ll extend the VS “14” experience with an automated fix to get your users back on track. If you develop library code for .NET, either public or for your own company, come see how to take them to the next level by turning them into Code Aware Frameworks.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Building Code Aware Frameworks using the .NET Compiler Platform (“Roslyn”)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
At Bitly we serve over 6 billion clicks/per month, record each one, and do all sorts of analysis on that data to provide useful information back to our users.
As a company we face two major challenges: 1. Not breaking the Internet - if Bitly links stop working, a non-trivial part of the Internet just became much less useful. 2. Moving fast - we need to continually adapt to change and build new tools to provide more value to our users.
This presents the eternal challenge of accomplishing both stability and speed. This talk will cover the processes, approaches, and tools used to do over 20-30 deploys each day to over 400 servers without causing any major disruptions to service.
Some of the topics to be covered include: * Benefits of Service Oriented Architecture * Designing with ops in mind from day one * The power of NSQ (realtime distributed messaging) * Asynchronous > Synchronous (except when it isn't) * Designing for predictability * Route around failure (via hostpool) * Automate + Monitor ALL THE THINGS * Peer review for code + process
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Deploying all day without breaking the Internet

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Elasticsearch is a cloud-ready, super scalable search engine which is gaining a lot of popularity lately. It is mostly known for being extremely easy to setup and integrate with any technology stack.In this talk we will introduce Elasticdearch, and start by looking at some of its basic capabilities. We will demonstrate how it can be used for document search and even log analytics for DevOps and distributed debugging, and peek into more advanced usages like the real-time aggregations and percolation. Obviously, we will make sure to demonstrate how Elasticsearch can be scaled out easily to work on a distributed architecture and handle pretty much any load.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: ElasticSearch - Distributed search and analytics on BigData made easy

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Reviewing examples of some of the more popular applications available today on the App Store, this presentation will prepare developers by introducing some basic building blocks for creating rich applications that pop. Focusing on getting the ground work in place by addressing some common View Controller options, this presentation will build upon the fundamentals by exploring some hurdles like working with the keyboard in a TextView, creating a custom AlertView, getting a Buttons color just right, and controlling various 'outlets' and properties programmatically for different user interactions. We will also look at some basic Core Animation examples that can be utilized to make even the most drone of applications come to life and enhance the overall user experience.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: New to Native? - Getting Started with iOS Development

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Success is coming to those who deliver connected customer experiences. But brands are struggling to reach consumers across channels while battling lagging infrastructures, social immaturity, and talent shortages. When influencers are everywhere and everything is important, how do you find your way through?
There is a familiar model to guide us; it's called parenthood.
Parents juggle countless decisions to create consistent experiences that deliver a foundation of well-being and growth. From the worlds toughest job — raising well-rounded, generally nice human beings — we learn how to consider long and short term outcomes, handling risk, and investing in what really matters.
Successful omnichannel models are rare in the current climate of disconnected technologies. I’ll explore how we manage the responsibility to consider every context and touchpoint.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Parenting is Experience Design: The Ultimate Omnichannel Case Study

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Is your codebase growing out of control and becoming difficult to maintain? Do you have too many teams working in that codebase causing scary merge conflicts? Maybe you want to write that new feature with Node.js but don't want to convert everything to javascript.
In this talk, you'll be introduced to some infrastructural techniques used at Groupon to increase the scalability and maintainability of applications. You'll learn how those techniques can be used to replace entire monolithic applications one piece at a time with a small application ecosystem. By the end of the talk you'll walk away with an understanding of how to support an effective polyglot engineering team.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Polyglot Architecture at Scale

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Every Java developer should have a good working knowledge of JVM bytecode. It’s fun, it can help you diagnose problems, improve performance, and even opens the door to building languages of your own. No matter what kind of Java application you work on, you’ll get something out of this talk.
We’ll start with bytecode fundamentals. You’ll learn how the most common operations work and see visual representations of how the JVM executes that code. The second part of the talk will introduce Jitescript, a Java library for generating bytecode. You’ll learn how to use Jitescript with some plain old Java code to create your own JVM languages.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Programming with JVM Bytecode

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Be afraid. Be very afraid. For you are about to enter the mysterious and foreboding land of regular expressions. A land of strange-looking hieroglyphics. A land of many flavors and implementations. A land whose inhabitants possess seemingly magical powers over text. But fear no more, for you needn't make the journey alone: a guide and a map await you.
In this session, we'll take a whirlwind tour of the features found in most regular expression implementations. We'll dive deep. And take a peek *inside* a regular expression engine. From character literals to character classes, from backreferences to look-around, you'll see every step a regular expression engine takes when it parses text. By the end of the session, you'll be able to think *like* a regular expression engine.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Regular Expressions (now you have two problems)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Imagine diagramming your application like a map. The methods might be like cities and the classes like states. The more coupled two methods or classes are, the closer their cities or states may be to each other. Let's spread this map out before us and ask, "how do we best deploy our tests across this landscape"? There are many different kinds of test (unit, acceptance, etc.), each serving a different purpose. What mix of these will best cover the terrain? Well positioned tests can give us confidence in our code, document business rules, support refactoring, and make building new features easier. But poorly positioned tests can just as easily undermine all these goals. How do you find the right balance and test deployment strategy for your application's landscape? In this talk, we will look at the tradeoffs in the different kinds of tests and survey recommendations for deploying them effectively.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The Cartography of Testing
