PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Do you have a hard time in social situations? Find it hard to talk in front of a crowd? This session is designed to give developers concrete techniques for overcoming these fears in order to succeed in social situations. Principles discussed will include how to appropriately meet new people, strike up conversations, and be comfortable in social situations. There will also be specific discussions for dealing with difficult situations in a graceful manner. The session will be highly collaborative, include demonstrations and audience participation.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The Social Developer

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Hardware engineers have developed a large number of devices that can peer into the universe and turn its properties into numbers. How do these devices work? How do they communicate with computers? What sorts of problems show up when using them?
This talk demonstrates a collection of interesting sensors and how a computer uses them to measure properties of its environment such as temperature, pressure, and position.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Things With Which to Measure the Universe

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
What if simply writing tests was enough to produce a program which makes them pass? What if your compiler could guarantee that your “Heartbleed-free” OpenSSL replacement follows the TLS specification to the letter, and even finds inconsistencies in the specification itself? What if you could write a test which showed that your code had no unintentional behavior, ever? Microsoft Research is well known for its contributions to Kinect, F#, the Entity Framework, and more, but it's also the home of a number of programming tools which do things which many programmers would consider surprising, if not impossible. But they work, and in this session you'll see them in action.
The Dafny language can check contracts at compile time. The Z3 theorem prover can solve problems from specifications alone, and is used to make Hyper-V and Windows Azure memory safe. The F7 specification language for F# was used by its authors used it to not only produce a TLS implementation which provably follows the spec, but also identified a dangerous hole in the TLS specification itself. You'll learn how Amazon uses the TLA+ specification language to prove that there are no edge cases in its internal protocols. Far from being research toys, these tools are in daily use in cases where stability, security, and reliability of code matters most. Can they help with your hardest problems? You might be surprised!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Your Flying Car is Ready: Amazing Programming Tools of the Future, Today!

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Most people think of functional languages such as F# as good at math or complex problem solving. It is actually fantastic for a very wide array of tasks, including web programming. Tachyus was able to go from 0 to production in 12 weeks using F#, replacing existing automated and manual systems for their first client. While this presentation focuses on F#, the talk is generally applicable to those interested in applying functional programming practices to their web applications. In this talk, we evolve a web application written in the familiar MVC pattern to simpler, functional patterns available to functional languages like F# and exercise features such as function composition, computation expressions (async), type providers, and active patterns.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Zero to Production in Twelve Weeks with F# on the Web

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Thursday Dinner
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Dinner

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: The MakerGear team will drop-in from Cleveland for 3D Printing After Dark. They'll talk about 3D modeling, preparing your models for printing and, of course, 3D Printing! They'll have printers, a 3D printed drone, a 3D printed violin and perhaps some other odds and ends. The session is informal and based on your questions.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: 3D Printing

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: As .NET developers, we depend on DLLs. However they don't always do exactly what we we'd like them to. The class we need is marked internal or the DLL itself was released with bugs. Luckily we can fix all that. Join Josh as he shows you how to manipulate DLLs both manually and programatically with Mono.Cecil. We'll walk through the hotfix of a bug in the Roslyn compiler by rewriting one of the DLLs released by Microsoft. We'll explore how signed DLLs work, why they don't offer protection against DLL manipulation and why that's probably a good thing.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: All your DLLs are belong to us.

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: In this world of ever increasing opportunities to purchase ‘toys’ classified as ‘drones’… have you ever wanted to fly a drone? Have you ever asked yourself the question… should I buy a drone or build? This presentation will discuss why the term ‘drone’ should be most generally referred to as… ‘multi-rotor copter’ and not UAV (unmanned autonomous vehicle) or drone. This presentation will discuss the basics of how a multi-rotor works… the steps to build a multi-rotor… including details on flight controllers, frame selection, motors and props (including determining what type of multi-rotor will suite your purpose), speed controllers and batteries. There are a lot of variables… all of these details will be broken down, making the process of building your first copter a ‘flight in the park’. At the end… a flying multi-rotor copter will be air-worthy and demonstrated.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Build Your Own Drone - From the Ground Up

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Using a custom deck of Extreme Programming playing cards, we will play a game that will challenge your knowledge of XP problems, solutions, and values. This game is fun for both new and experienced XPers.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Extreme Programming Explanations

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Come play with the Oculus Rift and see what Facebook paid $2 Billion for. Get to play a game head to head (literally) with your best friend, random stranger, or even your nemesis! Kids welcome.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Head to Head Oculus Rift VR Smashdown!1!!1

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: With over $1 billion in funding across 76,000 projects Kickstarter is the biggest crowd funding platform on the planet. Zack Chapple will take you through a first hand experience on how he created a successfully funded campaign and the lessons learned along the way.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Kickstart your dreams - lessons from a successful campaign

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: (121 min) (PG-13) Bring a beverage. Popcorn will be provided
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: KM Movie: Guardians of the Galaxy

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Welcome to the world of LEGO Robotics and robotic competitions. We'll briefly discuss FIRST and the FIRST LEGO League and give a quick overview of the new Mindstorms EV3 robot. Then we will write a reusable program to easily control the movements of a LEGO robot. If time permits, we'll also write a simple line following program.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Lego Robotics

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: The NodeBot battles and races are over, but that doesn’t mean you are left in the dust. Which bots reigned supreme? What crazy contraptions did people come up with? Want to see how JavaScript works with hardware? Just want to nerd out with the state of hobby electronics? The NodeBots AfterDark OpenHouse is a place to see what is possible when people get creative and hack. We may even have some hardware leftover to noodle with!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Node Bots - AfterDark

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: PK is basically speaker karaoke. Each deck is ten slides with twenty seconds each, on an automatic timer. It is always very entertaining. Potential speakers will sign up their topics near the Open Spaces sign up, and all attendees can vote. The top sessions will be scheduled to present, with a battle at the end with a sight unseen deck. Always very entertaining.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Pecha Kucha

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Battle other CodeMash attendees in local multiplayer “steam” games. Highlights include “Nidhogg” (fencing), “TowerFall Ascension” (archery) and “Worms Reloaded” (artillery strategy), other “steam” games will be available depending on want attendees want to play. Don’t worry if you’ve never played these game before, what better place to learn than CodeMash? If we have enough numbers/interest we will have a “Nidhogg" and/or “Towerfall Ascension" tournament.
I have a windows 7 laptop that I’ll have these games installed on and xbox 360 controllers for games that work best on controllers. All you need to bring is your appetite for battle!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Renaissance Men Unite — Battle To The Death!

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Are you ready to win the greatest secure coding challenge that has ever existed? Welcome to BRAINS AND THE BUTS, Secure Coding After Dark Edition. This game show format challenges programmers to answer a variety of questions regarding secure coding and security engineering. The greatest BRAINS will win a variety of fun prizes like cheap iPad tablet knock-offs.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Secure Coding - After Dark - Brains and the Buts

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
There will be two shuttles running loops through all of the official hotels. There is a scheduled loop during the morning and evenings, and an on-demand shuttle through the rest of the day.
You can use our website to track where the shuttle is, shuttle.codemash.org. You can see where the shuttles are in real time.
The shuttle will pick up and drop off by Entrance A in the conference center (near the attendee registration booth and the giant lion). The shuttle will pick up and drop off by the main lobby doors of each hotel. The shuttles are available to attendees and their families.
Afternoon: (Expect a delay) Call for Pickup Complimentary service to area hotels. Call Kalahari Concierge for Pickup (FIFO) (419) 433-7200 x34089
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Shuttle

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: This will be the largest game of Catan you’ve ever played (unless you were in the 922-player version of this at Gen Con two years ago)! Thirty players, ninety minutes, one board, lots of fun! Sign up for the game in the Open Gaming Room before Thursday evening.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Catan: The Big Game

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Enjoy a cash bar (and the drink tickets you were given at badge pickup) as well as appetizers, and music during the attendee party. Families are welcome.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Attendee Party

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Join your fellow musicians on the main stage, where we will have a complete set of instruments for you to play with. You can even bring your own instruments. Bagpipes not included, but families are.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Jam Session

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: The waterpark will open for CodeMash attendees (and families) only, as a private event. About half of the rides will be operating. Many sponsors will have fun activities at various cabanas, and the KidzMash cabanas will also be up and running.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Private Access Waterpark Party

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
There will be two shuttles running loops through all of the official hotels. There is a scheduled loop during the morning and evenings, and an on-demand shuttle through the rest of the day.
You can use our website to track where the shuttle is, shuttle.codemash.org. You can see where the shuttles are in real time.
The shuttle will pick up and drop off by Entrance A in the conference center (near the attendee registration booth and the giant lion). The shuttle will pick up and drop off by the main lobby doors of each hotel. The shuttles are available to attendees and their families.
Afternoon: (Expect a delay) Call for Pickup Complimentary service to area hotels. Call Kalahari Concierge for Pickup (FIFO) (419) 433-7200 x34089
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Shuttle

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
There will be two shuttles running loops through all of the official hotels. There is a scheduled loop during the morning and evenings, and an on-demand shuttle through the rest of the day.
You can use our website to track where the shuttle is, shuttle.codemash.org. You can see where the shuttles are in real time.
The shuttle will pick up and drop off by Entrance A in the conference center (near the attendee registration booth and the giant lion). The shuttle will pick up and drop off by the main lobby doors of each hotel. The shuttles are available to attendees and their families.
Afternoon: (Expect a delay) Call for Pickup Complimentary service to area hotels. Call Kalahari Concierge for Pickup (FIFO) (419) 433-7200 x34089
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Shuttle

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Visit the booth for all your registration needs and conference questions.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Registration Booth - Friday

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Friday Breakfast
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Breakfast

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
A structured conversation about what we'll learn at CodeMash, what we'll do when we come home ... and whatever else we'd like to discover.
Grab coffee and meet in Rosewood.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Lean Coffee (Day 4)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Come play the best starship bridge simulator you’ve even seen. Twice the awesome this year with twice as many bridges. Take over a touchscreen station to help your team beat the scenarios. No team? No problem, just drop in. We’ll match you up.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Artemis Bridge Simulator

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Look for the reserved waterpark cabanas for attendees and their families. Great place to drop your gear, meet other attendees (or CodeMash families), and hang out.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Cabanas

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Drop in and play a game. Sponsored by Improving Enterprises. We also have Mayfair games back this year, with their giant sized versions of some of their most popular games.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Game Room

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: The use of this room varies, but it’s filled with lots of furniture. Drop in and hang out.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Lounge

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Feel free to store your luggage, at your own risk.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Luggage Storage

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Open spaces are available all day Thursday and Friday. Sign up near Entrance A for session times.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Open Spaces

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: This year we have a dedicated hotel room near the conference for people who need someplace for prayer time, or a quiet place to handle some personal things (breast feeding, etc). Not for office/work duties. Check in at the reg booth for the room key.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Prayer & Quiet Room

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Out of the box, ASP.NET can do a lot of amazing things. The tools and framework have grown to make mundane tasks, such as minification, simple to implement. Many times by using the framework as we were taught, opportunities to optimize pass us by. The reality is that underneath the covers, there is a whole world of easy tweaks we can implement to help ASP.NET perform at its peak.
In this presentation, we will walk through a slew of tweaks used to make ASP.NET perform in the best way possible. You will leave with a checklist of tasks that will instantly improve the performance of your web application!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: ASP.NET Performance Tips and Tricks

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Code duplication threatens the agility and maintainability of software. Literally repeated code can be easily remedied, but there are other more subtle and insidious kinds of code duplication. What about code that's the same except for type, or code that needs to be applied in many locations? In this session, you will learn about tools to help find duplicate code. After identifying problem code, you will learn how to eradicate it with software design techniques and .NET framework features. Specifically, you will see how to apply generics, delegates, extension methods, and attributes to quash repeated code. You will leave with ideas and techniques to reduce duplicated code in your development.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Attack of the clones: Eliminating duplicate code in .NET

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
In the old days, you were a small, scrappy startup, cranking out code just fast enough to make the deadline and get the next deal closed. Now, you're a Serious Business, and Important People wearing Important Suits are asking you Important Questions about how secure your software is. And they don't like the "{hot new framework} is taking care of that for us" answer. So what do you do?
Easy: OWASP has you covered. The Top Ten are the most common vulnerabilities you'll encounter, but they're pretty easy to avoid if you know how. There's even example code for each one -- it's in Ruby on Rails, but that's not the point. The point is to answer Important Questions and get back to hacking.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Basics of Rails Application Security

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Just because you get your Platform As A Service, doesn't mean you get a free pass on security. Sure, lots has been done to make sure you fall into the pit of success. We will start with securing Azure Websites, and move to Blob Storage, Service Bus, and Databases.
All of the Demo's and descriptions in this talk should be highly accessible to all, even if you've never given cloud security a thought. You will walk away with some very quick and easy to implement steps to secure your Azure PAAS apps.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Covering Your PAAS : Securing Azure Platform As A Service Offerings

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Pow! Splatt! Boom! When most people think of comics they think of larger than life heroes or over the top cartoon characters. But what makes these big ideas work? It’s the spaces in between--the details that tie all the elements together, make the big moments gigantic, and the special moments memorable.
It’s the same with design. Whether you’re wireframing an app or building a corporate website, the design is the story you tell.
You’ve already learned everything you need to know to about user centered design from comics. Brad will guide you through the basics and explain how design can tell the big stories, the little stories, and everything in between.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Everything I Know About Design I Learned from Comics

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Bring your laptop to this hands-on session of doing exploratory testing - a customer-value-centric style of testing that does not require boring paperwork (yet can still stand up to scrutinty.) Instead of planning the work and working the plan, Exploratory testing combines test design, execution, reporting and learning in a simultaneous process. Done well it can be a powerful tool in any team member's arsenal. Done poorly, ET can create confusion without adding much value. Learning by doing, we'l pair with a buddy, hear a little theory, and then get to testing. We'll have some more theory, then test a second application, then a third - then conduct a retrospective to talk about how these techniques can combine to improve coverage of the application, reducing time-to-done, and allow teams to compress testing into iterations, sprints, and other timeboxes.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Exploratory Testing for Everybody!

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: It's your information, why don't you use it? Too many times, businesses and developers collect different forms of text-based data that then go unused, collecting dust in some data warehouse. This session will introduce developers to several ways businesses are leveraging text analytics and natural language processing to improve business practices or inform decision-making processes. Types of data used in the examples may include company websites, invoices, record narratives and social media. The majority of examples and tools demonstrated will be python based. The means to extract usable, structured information from unstructured text and add it to your data arsenal is within your grasp!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Get the most out of your text-based data

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Having trouble groking git? Not sure what the difference between merging and rebasing is? Wondering what you would ever use a "cherry-pick" for? We'll cover these topics and more in this talk, helping you get past git novice and on your way to git master.
We'll do a short review of git, then dive deeper into: branches, commit amending, git logs, merging and rebasing, cherry-picking, stashing, and more.
Okay, maybe you won't be a guru after one conference session, but you will have a better understanding of how to play nicely with others in the same git repository.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Gitting More Out of Git

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: This talk will go into detail about creating an automated meat smoker using two different hardware platforms. It will describe the implementation details about the hardware and software components to build the smoker. We will start with exploring the implementation on the Arduino microcontroller. Then we will go through the challenges and benefits of porting the automated smoker to the Raspberry Pi platform.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: How I built an automated meat smoker on Arduino and then Raspberry Pi

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
The challenge of modelling and balancing the economy of a large scale game is one of the biggest problems game developers face and one that many have tried to solve by simply throwing man-hours at it... But there's a better way!
Learn how Gamesys does it by leveraging graph database Neo4j to model the in-game economy of their MMORPG "Here Be Monsters" and automate the balancing process. In this session Yan Cui will discuss lessons learned, successes and challenges, and how a graph database enables a small team of game designers to stay agile and focused on delivering new content to players.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Modelling complex game economy with Neo4j

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Node.js is fast. It's asynchronous. It's Hacker News worthy, and it runs your Javascript on V8. Of course V8 is a great Javascript runtime brought to you by some very talented developers. But what about us poor souls who live our lives on the Java Virtual Machine? With 3 choices available today - Rhino, Nashorn and DynJS, it is possible to run Javascript on the JVM. But what about Node? Node.js is mostly Javascript, so surely it can't be too hard to run it on the JVM. In this talk you'll learn what it take to run your Node.js applications along side your Java bits.
The presentation will explore the Node.js process bindings which couple it with V8. You will see how the Nodyn project (http://nodyn.io) uses these bindings, along with the DynJS Javascript runtime (http://dynjs.org) and Netty (http://netty.io) for asynchronous IO, to provide a viable Node.js environment on the JVM. There will be some code examples, and you'll get a glimpse into the nitty gritty details that make Nodyn and Node.js on the JVM possible.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Process Bindings: How to do Node.js on the JVM

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Regardless of how you feel about felines, dead cats stink.
What also stinks is what is happening to agile development practices. What started as a movement to increase quality and usefulness of code written, has been professionalized into certificates and ceremonies that are only marginally helping the process. Instead of blaming political and organizational forces, this humorous and irreverent talk focuses on what team members can do to overcome these corporate obstacles and to get to the spirit of agile through a focus on architectural innovation and personal improvement. Attendees should expect to laugh, to learn from the experience of implementing dozens of real world enterprise agile teams, and to come out with proven new techniques to try to bring more satisfaction to how they do their work and to bring the focus of agile back to software development.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Reclaiming agile development: don't let the cat die...

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: This session will “walk" through the CoreMotion framework. The Core Motion framework contains a lot of useful data that can be analyzed to understand what the user or the device itself is doing by reading the measurements of the iOS device. Along the way we will create a pedometer app and demonstrate several other facets of CoreMotion.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Taking a Stroll with CoreMotion

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Starting a business is a dream for many professionals, and IT pros are no exception. The draw of independence, self-reliance, growth and profit potential are all very appealing to the right kind of individual. Indeed being a freelance consultant or part of a small company can prove to be extraordinarily rewarding.
However, as folks say, "with great power comes great responsibility." Running a software business is about a lot more than writing code. This session will consider the easily overlooked, but ever-important, legal and tax implications of your actions and decisions as a business owner.
The discussion will delve into the major issues facing new small businesses. Topics include finding the right advisors; choosing an appropriate business entity (e.g., partnership, corporation, LLC); asset protection for your business and your family; taxes; and how to actually pay yourself.
Armed with a bit of knowledge and the right questions, you will be able to approach your legal and tax advisors confidently, empowered to make the best possible decisions for your situation.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The Business Side of Starting Your Business

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: The 2.0.1.5 scavenger hunt is on! Go to Hangoutz to pick up the clue sheet and roam the conference to find the answers. Do not be in a hurry as this is NOT a race. Not only do you have all day Thursday, but half the day on Friday to complete your quest! When you are done return to Hangoutz to have your answers checked and receive a sticker good towards a second ticket to distribute at the raffle.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: KidzMash: Scavenger Hunt (Part 2)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Birds travel thousands of miles each year to migrate, flying for hours on very little food and rest. By comparison, migrating databases seems like a paltry feat.
Birdwave is a way to visualize the amazing phenomenon of bird migration. Using ClojureScript and Om allowed the app to be written in a declarative, concise manner, taking full advantage of JavaScript interoperability, as well as Clojure's awesome built-in features such as persistent data structures and the async module. Also, prepare to be dazzled by the data-viz powerhouse that is D3.
No birds were harmed in the creation of Birdwave. Or this talk.
App site: http://birdwave.neo.com
Related blog posts: http://www.neo.com/2014/04/21/choropleths-and-d3js, http://www.neo.com/2014/07/18/using-the-flickr-api-with-clojurescript
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: A Bird's Eye View of ClojureScript

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: What is your code coverage? Why not 10% more or less? Is testing this feature more important than shipping the next? Many teams spend too much time and energy on testing the wrong things. In this session, an enterprise developer turned startup entrepreneur will dive into the costs and benefits of testing. You will learn about the organizational and social dynamics that drives teams to over-test. You will come away armed to convince your team, your manager, and your business to ship more and maximize test value. Check your dogma at the door and let's ship some valuable software.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Are You Over-Testing?

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: With the introduction of Google's Android Wear, you are no longer restricted to just phones and tablets when it comes to developing great Android apps. You want notifications on your wrist? You got it. You want to run an app on your wrist? You got it. In this session, let me take you through the awesome new features of Android Wear and the tools required to start building the apps you want for Wear. We'll extend a current app with rich notifications and even create a brand new app from scratch live on stage that runs right on your Android Wear device. All demonstrations will be coded in C#, but will be applicable to any Android developer in any language.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Building Your First Android Wear App

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Developers are lazy! So we are great in creating tooling for our daily work. But it has its weaknesses, we are creating a tons of scripts on our local machine, sometimes we share them via git or other vcs systems. But all over all this tooling sucks when it comes to collaboration. We developers also love hanging out in chat rooms like campfire or jabber.
Why not combine this via chat robots. Our tooling would be available to everyone without installing wired shell scripts plus we can get rid if questions like: “Do you have the deploy lock?” or “Did you already migrate the database?” - it’s all documented in the transcripts.
I’d like to talk about how to improve your daily work with hubot (http://hubot.github.com/), a chat robot build by the fine folks at github.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Chat Robots Next Level Tooling

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Anyone can write code a computer can understand, but professional developers write code *humans* can understand. This session discusses best practices for writing code in a style that’s easy to create, maintain and understand. We have a lofty goal: programming style as documentation. We’ll discuss concrete methods to get you there and give you a vocabulary for pragmatically evaluating code quality. Various refactoring techniques, code smells, and best practices are discussed including fail fast, return early, arrow code, being “stringly typed”, the outline rule, and table-driven methods. Part of this session involves refactoring a confusing and ugly chunk of code into something beautiful, easy to read and maintain. While examples are in C#, coders in any language should be able to follow along and apply the principles discussed.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Clean Code: Writing Code for Humans

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: In this session we'll explore the OpenBCI (Open Brain Computer Interface), Arduino compatible, board. This board allows sampling of brain activity (EEG). Using these samples, we can make use of them for control of other devices.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Control your computer with your Brain!

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Web application security has never been harder. Our adversary is cunning and clever, and with software becoming more and more complex its harder than ever to ensure security. This presentation is about using Aspect Oriented Programming to help organize our code in a way that makes implementing security practices easier, centrally maintained and helps to bring security to the forefront of the software development process. Our aim is to slow or stop our attackers on multiple levels using AOP as our mechanism for achieving this.
Code for this talk will be in C# with PostSharp however the concepts can be applied to virtually any programming language or AOP tool.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Defense in Depth with AOP

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: While Machine Learning practitioners routinely use a wide range of tools and languages, C# is conspicuously absent from that arsenal. Is .NET inadequate for Machine Learning? In this talk, I'll argue that it can be a great fit, as long as you use the right language for the job, namely F#. F# is a functional-first language, with a concise and expressive syntax that will feel familiar to data scientists used to Python or Matlab. It combines the performance and maintainability benefits of statically typed languages, with the flexibility of Type Providers, a unique mechanism that enables seamless consumption of virtually any data source. And as a first-class .NET citizen, it interops smoothly with C#. So if you are interested in a language that can handle both flexible data exploration and the pressure of a real production system, come check out what F# has to offer.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: F# and Machine Learning: a Winning Combination

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Performance in the cloud comes from the ability to scale out. Unfortunately, your options to scale up instead of out in the cloud can often be limited and in some cases even the biggest cloud instance you can provision is far less powerful than the on premise server you are migrating from.
This presentation will share techniques and lessons learned from real world experience when deploying large existing ASP.Net/SQL Server applications to Windows Azure. While some abstract concepts will be discussed, the primary focus of this presentation will be to give attendees practical technical solutions that can be applied to dramatically improve performance in the cloud without major code/architecture changes and in many cases the techniques covered in this presentation are also highly effective in non-cloud environments.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: From Scale up to Scale Out - Migrating our App from Big Iron to the Cloud

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
I don’t know about you, but vanilla CSS always leaves me wanting more. It’s a fairly simple language, can do some pretty powerful things, but after a while... well, it can become rather tedious to work with.
Enter Sass: Syntactically Awesome Stylesheets. Sass is a CSS meta-language and precompiler that makes the prettification of your website a breeze by adding invaluable features of more traditional programming languages.
In this workshop, we’ll jump right in to the Sass workflow and cover all the key game changers - nesting, variables, mixins, inheritance, and directives. We’ll also cover some of the gotchyas, tools and extensions, and tips on organization and coding standards.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Getting Sassy With CSS

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
"Oh no! I just typed something into git and now my work is gone! Ahh!"
Don't panic. Contrary to popular belief, git is one of the most non-destructive version control systems available. When used right, git never loses any data, and even when misused, chances are very high you can still recover.
This talk will present turn-by-turn directions on how to recover from a wide array of common git mistakes, and also provide some workflows to minimize them.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: git gone wild: how to recover from common git mistakes.

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
In 2003, a new hire at Microsoft was happily toiling away in obscurity working on an online service. On nights and weekends, he built a little tool to help the team test the site. And then things got interesting.
In this talk, Fiddler-builder Eric Lawrence explains how Fiddler grew from a rough side-project to a powerful and popular tool used by millions worldwide. After a brief overview of its technical evolution, the session covers never-before-revealed details about how Fiddler "escaped" from Microsoft and the long and stressful acquisition process. He shares lessons learned, what he'd do differently today, and inspiration for others hoping to convert their passion into their full-time job.
If you've ever wanted to peek "behind the scenes," you'll enjoy this session.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Lucking In: Growing Fiddler from a side-project to my full-time job

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Ever wondered how some of the apps on your iPhone/iPad always seem to launch with up-to-date information from the server? Or how the download of large file completes even after you switched out of the app to a different one while the download is still in progress? Find out how these and other such capabilities are enabled in this talk on multitasking support on the iOS platform. Multitasking is the ability to run multiple apps on the device at the same time. Previously available in restricted form to a certain category of apps, now with iOS7, Apple introduced some powerful advancements to this feature. The platform now uses an intelligent algorithm that guarantees optimal battery usage while ensuring that all apps get a fair chance to run in the background. Making this even more powerful is the ability for data transfers to occur even when the app is not running! This talk will discuss and demonstrate the multitasking capabilities on the iOS platform and the APIs that you can leverage to support these capabilities within your own apps. This talk is recommended for anyone developing or interested in developing apps for the iPhone/iPad.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Multitasking Support on the iOS Platform

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: You may have seen angular. You may have seen Meteor. But did you know you could use them *gasp* together?! In this session we'll see how Angular and Meteor compliment one another perfectly. We'll see how they let you build a real time web app with persistent data in astonishingly little code. We'll demonstrate how you can add authentication via github or twitter almost for free. Finally, we'll see you can deploy your new app to a live server in only a few minutes. Expect to come away being able to build an angular/meteor app and have a blast doing it.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Ridiculously fast web app development with Angular and Meteor

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Want your Hadoop environment to sizzle like bacon? Perfect, because in the time it takes to fry 4 pounds of bacon, we'll identify causes of common performance issues in Big Data environments, discuss heap size, garbage collection, and JVM reuse tuning guidelines plus recommend tools to analyze your Big Data application performance.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Tuning Java for Big Bacon ... er, Big Data!

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Java Enterprise Edition (JEE) is a mainstay of many enterprises. However, even after 15 years of use in the industry, there still isn't an easy way to create a consistent development environment for all team members and unit test server-deployed components. JEE developers still experience the pain of big bang integration testing unless they're willing to put forth the time intensive work required to create unit-testable server-deployed components. Using Docker and Maven in conjunction with SoapUI makes it easy to unit test server-deployed components. This session demonstrates how using Docker in your continuous integration environment brings new levels of agility to JEE development. Along with a discussion of the benefits of creating layered Docker images, you will also learn how to:
Create a layered JEE Application Server image
Layer a domain on top of the JEE Application Server image
Autodeploy a JEE application to the domain
Use Maven in conjunction with SoapUI to unit test your component
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Using Docker and Maven to Develop and Unit Test JEE Components

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: COSI is joining us with 10 events to help us explore science related topics and have fun! Robots, motors, wind power, building challenges, electricity and much more. Come pick up a Tabletopz tracker and explore at your convenience. Receive a stamp at each table you explore then after 3 stamps get 1 KidzMash sticker. After earning 6 stamps get a 2nd KidzMash sticker good towards a 2nd raffle ticket at KidzMash Kaboomz!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: COSI

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
We’ve been taught that duplication is bad, and copy-paste programming is evil. The Don’t Repeat Yourself principle tells us to stop the cycle of evil, but merely building abstractions only gets us a little DRY.
How can we get completely DRY? This is where conventions come in. Conventions can make your app smarter, getting rid of the obvious stuff without having to resort to more rudimentary tools like code generation.
You'll see common tools that embrace conventions, where they work well and what pitfalls to avoid. You’ll also look at building your own conventions in the web, mobile and more. Finally you'll look at diagnostics and testing to remove the magic that scares too many developers away.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Keeping yourself DRY with conventions

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Have you ever needed to access a data source in your application? Trick question! Are there developers who would answer no to that question? Of course not! Join me and I'll walk you through just how quick and easy data access can be with F#'s new Type Providers. I'll cover connecting to several different data sources using the relevant type providers, as well as when and how to write your own. Before we part, you'll be on your way to type provider mastery!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Consuming Data with F#'s Type Providers

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
A few years ago I gave one of my robots the job of turning on and off the lights based on sunrise/sunset. Later that years I added a little more functionality by asking it what I should wear everyday (shorts/jeans) based on the weather forecast. In 2014 I now have a dedicated server monitoring 9 network cameras for motion detection and performing face recognition, controlling TVs, thermostats, stereos, the coffee machine and many more things. I can even call my house on Skype to get statuses or tell it what to do.
In this talk I'll give an overview of all the modern systems used to control household appliances and lights. I'll give an overview of products with useful REST APIs and how to roll-your-own with a Raspberry PI and a a few inexpensive sensors. I'll also show you how I've built my own J.A.R.V.I.S. and give you an overview of the code and equipment for you to do the same.
As a bonus bring a new robot to the talk and show you how J.A.R.V.I.S. communicates with this robot and tells it what to do. Yes computers commanding robots without human input.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Creating J.A.R.V.I.S. - An Awesome Guide To Automating Your Home

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Make no mistake, data science can be hard, but it can also be fun. In this session I'll introduce you to Classic and Bayesian Statistics and Machine Learning, all through the medium of predicting horse racing results. We'll explore a number of techniques for making such predictions and finish by combining them into a powerful "mixed model" prediction engine that's sure to pick the next big winner. This session won't only improve your knowledge, it'll improve your bank balance too! Note: probably won't do the latter though. :-)
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Data Science for Fun and Profit

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Developers are ‘makers’. We like to get things done. The more productive we are, the happier we are. This connection between productivity and happiness has been researched in the field of positive psychology as flow: the theory that people are happiest when they are in a state of absorption with an activity, or in the zone (credit: M. Csiksgentmihalyi). Using LEGOs and other interactive exercises, this session will present how to effectively harness the power of flow to improve happiness while also producing high-quality deliverables. Participants will explore specific practices such as personal Kanban, the Pomodoro technique, and Test Driven Development.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Developer Flow: Harness the Power of Flow for Happier Developers

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Most samples, fixtures, stubs, and repetitive test-cases tend to fall short of completing their intended storyline: representing the range of possible values that will interact with a designated specification, whether that refers to a single function or a more integrated system. Why not just set some bounded constraints and generate a more exhaustive set of circumstances that your program or system is contracted and believed to satisfy? In this talk, through examples in Clojure’s test.check and Erlang’s QuickCheck, I’ll demonstrate how to easily compose and apply generators for various use-cases, including generating data from schema/validation libraries like Clojure's Prismatic Schema and Herbert and using a finite state machine to model stateful code with side-effects via Erlang QuickCheck’s eqc_statem. We can apply these generations toward all kinds of problem spaces: from testable database environments to property-based tests for capturing what’s true/valid and what better be false.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Generating Circumstances

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
ElasticSearch, Logstash, and Kibana (ELK) combine to make arbitrary and disparate logs accessible in one convenient and indexed location. When logs from different servers and applications are combined, the real power of logging becomes apparent. Using these 3 open-source technologies can super-charge real-time tracing, as well as enable mid and long-term trending analysis. ELK can even make logs interesting to Business and Product Analysts.
This session will highlight the simplicity and flexibility of ELK. The session will also show how OCLC used minor changes to the application logging to enhance event correlation, as well as the benefits the organization realized by moving logs through ELK.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Looking for Logs in all the Wrong Places: How ELK makes logging powerful

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Friday Lunch
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Lunch

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: The design landscape is much wider now than ever before: apps for devices of various sizes, smart tvs, game consoles, and an ever increasing number of platforms and resolutions have led the industry to broadly adopt responsive design as a tool. However, the design process has not kept up. Too often static comps are used as the only touchpoint between designers and decision makers, presenting the designs in an out of context and limiting format. What needs to be done is to adapt each step of the design process to convey scaling, device context, motion and interactivity to give a more realistic idea of how the designs work. Case studies and tools for prototyping and creating interactive mockups will be examined, and a discussion of how to revamp current processes for an ever changing design world.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: No More Static Comps: Design Process in the Modern World

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Glimpse, an open source web application diagnostics tool, went from a rough back-of-a-napkin idea to a project with tens of thousands of users and developer media attention within a period of eight weeks. Join Glimpse’s co-founder, Nik Molnar, for an honestly raw tale of the pains and lessons learned that arose managing an open source project. Along the way, Nik will cover the tools and techniques that have proven successful over the past two years developing Glimpse, focusing on technical challenges and best practices for community management, communications and open source/life balance.
This session is suitable for founders, maintainers, contributors and all users of open source software and aims to spark conversation around the best way to foster open source and open source etiquette.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Open Source Software : From Zero to Sixty

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
The OWASP Top Ten Proactive Controls is a list of security techniques that should be included in every software development project. They are ordered by order of importance, with control number 1 being the most important. This document was written by developers for developers to assist those new to secure development.
1: Parameterize Queries 2: Encode Data 3: Validate All Inputs 4: Implement Appropriate Access Controls 5: Establish Identity and Authentication Controls 6: Protect Data and Privacy 7: Implement Logging, Error Handling and Intrusion Detection 8: Leverage Security Features of Frameworks and Security Libraries 9: Include Security-Specific Requirements 10: Design and Architect Security In
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: OWASP Top Ten Proactive Approaches to Software Security

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Trying to do test driven development for Android applications can be a painful process and cause an already receding hairline to accelerate. The Android Test framework is slow, and requires either an emulator or a physical device to test upon. There are other solutions like Robotium or UIAutomator but these lend themselves to writing tests that drive the UI and lean toward Integration tests. While these are necessary part of testing, they don't provide quick feed back to the developer.
This talk will discuss lessons learned from using Robolectric 2.3 and Mockito to bring some sanity to unit testing Android applications. Allowing for a true test driven development with fast test execution and fast developer feedback of failures. We will review some dos and don'ts when using Robolectric, and when Mockito may be a better fit. Examples will be shown from using these frameworks to provide unit test coverage for an Android TV application, but the same techniques can be used for any Android application.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Stop Going Bald trying to Unit Test Android Applications.

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Web frameworks help you build an API quickly but most have little support for dealing with an API that needs to evolve, forcing you to prematurely version your API.
Take back control of the content you send over the wire. API responses are the "user interface" of your API and should be crafted with same attention to detail that cause designers to fret over color choices, shadows and highlights.
In this talk I’ll show you what I have learned about API response design in the last 8 years of building Web APIs. I'll cover issues like structuring for evolution, sizing for optimum caching, the different ways to include metadata, media type selection and many other issues that surface when trying to design an API for the long haul.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Take control of your interface - Crafting API responses for your clients

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Modern frontend development requires an unparalleled number of auxiliary tools to get the job done. Frontend devs are forced to think about 3rd party package managers, CSS precompilers, Javascript code linters, design frameworks like Bootstrap, Javascript module systems, and of course Javascript frameworks and toolsets like Ember, Angular, or Backbone.
Is the Javascript community crazy? Yes. Are all these disparate tools a bad thing? No. Not if you have a good build system.
In this talk, learn how to use gulp.js to combine the best of these Javascript and frontend tools and improve your development quality and speed. You will walk away with useable code for your build system as well as practical examples of how to create organized, modular Javascript code.
This talk is for anyone who has to get their hands dirty with Javascript on the web.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Tame your frontend stack with gulp.js

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Microsoft Azure Mobile Services provides a straightforward way to expose backend services to multiple applications on multiple devices. In this presentation, I will show how to expose cloud data access and other processes via a REST interface and connect to that data from applications running on Windows Phone, Windows 8, iOs and Android. You will also learn how to secure these services; how to scale these services to meet volatile demand; how to push notifications to client apps; and how to manage Mobile Services from within Visual Studio.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to Azure Mobile Services

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: This presentation will provide a concise, but thorough, review of one of the more unique features of the F# language: active recognizers. Also known as active patterns, this feature allows one to extend the pattern-matching capabilities of the language. Active recognizers may be put to great effect in taming unruly APIs, improving the declarative style of one's code, constructing embedded DSLs, and much more. This talk will be given in a lecture format, interspersing digestible code samples with detailed breakdown of syntax. Additional consideration will be given, time permitting, to appropriate use-cases for active recognizers and a discussion of the under-lying mechanics. The review is aimed at advanced beginners who are familiar with F#'s general syntax and usage. Also, while not strictly necessary, those wishing to follow along via computer are encouraged to have, at least, version 2.0 of the core F# tools. Information on obtaining the latest version of F# (for your platform of choice) may be found at: http://fsharp.org.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: (Nearly) Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About Active Recognizers (but were Afraid to Ask )

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: There's more to being a successful developer than simply being great at programming. The gotchas that slow us down or trip us up are often outside of the code we write, manifesting instead in our process or how we work with our peers. Whether you're new to programming or a veteran of many projects, these 5 things can improve your code, your career, and your team. If you're just starting out, you'll be glad to hear that you frustrations are not unique -- there are strategies for overcoming them. For experienced developers, this talk is a refresher course on what goes into the day-to-day, remind
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: 5 Things I Wish Someone Had Told Me About Programming Before I Started

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Our platforms and development environments keep offering better debugging support, but debugging is still a game of strategy. It’s a critical game because we fix bugs from the time we first check in code, and the cost of each bug tends to increase across the project lifecycle. Come to this talk to merge strategy with the debugging tools in your environment. In the examples, you’ll see debugging features in the current version of Visual Studio and upcoming in Visual Studio “14,” along with Windows features like ETW (Event Tracing for Windows). Good debugging strategies let you ask better questions and tools offer an array of tactics to efficiently answer most questions. Strategies and tactics differ a bit depending on the difficulty of the bug and where you can reproduce it. If it occurs only in production and remote debugging is not possible in your scenario, you’ll debug through piles of information. Find out what Windows can provide for you, without changing your application, and small changes to your application that increase the value of this information. Leave this talk ready to formulate ideas into testable strategies you can execute to resolve bugs faster and with more confidence.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Better Code, Better Debugging

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: When Java came on to the scene, it changed everything…. Now almost 20 years later, while the language starts to show its age, the platform continues to be as fertile as ever. The JVM is the core of this ecosystem and everyday more languages are emerging from it. Scala, Clojure, Groovy, Jython, Jruby, Ceylon, XTrend… the list goes on and on. With all these languages to choose from, how do programmers decide which languages are right for the job? In this session, you’ll learn about some of these popular JVM languages, and explore how to choose the right language to fit your needs.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Fantastic JVM Languages and Where to Find Them

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
As a software consultant, I get to see a lot of interesting code. In this particular instance a client was in the process of transforming their web application to a rich, interactive interface with the help of another company.
The project kicked off using Backbone and things were great. Until they were not great. Pages starting getting more and more involved and blame started being thrown at the technology choice.
A move to Ember.js ensued and the app was rewritten. But architecturally bad decisions don't hide long, and soon the rewrite was preforming even worse.
That's when I stepped in, with the help of another consultant, to solve the performance issues once and for all. Our solution used Backbone.js and it was fast. This is that journey.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: From Backbone to Ember and Back(bone) Again

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
"A 12yo presenting App Dev at TED? An 11yo presenting Spark to a tech conference? That's crazy; my kids just want to play games!"
Do you remember what sparked your interest in technology? Everyone has a different story of how that spark ignited into a fire to #LearnAllTheThings. In this talk, Cori Drew will share the experiences that--as a geek and a parent--left her surprised and enlightened, and will cover tactical ideas of how to ignite that fire in your own kids.
Share in the retrospective that led her daughter from a video-gaming 7yo to an 11yo speaker, and walk away with concepts of how to carry our passion for programming to our youth.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Ignition: Geek Parenting's Lessons Learned…so far

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: StructureMap is the oldest, continuously used IoC container for .Net. In the course of 10+ years developing and evolving StructureMap, I've learned a lot of painful lessons about the design decisions that can make modification and extension harder, hamper usability, and how to shoot yourself in the foot over performance. I’ve had a front row seat to how our ideas about framework and tooling usability have changed from out of control Xml configuration to way too many attributes to fluent interface “experimentation” to using conventional approaches and simpler API's. Unfortunately, I’ve created usability problems and hidden framework behavior that I’ve had to fix over the years and I’ve had to learn how to cater to user’s problems rather than the internal details of the framework. I’ve had to continuously work over the diagnostic capabilities of StructureMap to try to unravel nasty “why won’t this work!” episodes. In short, come to this talk and I might be able to help you dodge some of the problems I’ve faced over the past decade.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Lessons Learned from a Long Lived Codebase

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Now that mobile apps are invading the enterprise, and security breaches are a reality, an authenticated login is vital. When building web sites, login security gets taken for granted, because the browser utilizes lots of security mechanisms with built-in functionality created by armies of developers over many years. Mobile apps don't quite get this for free. Mobile authentication should leverage mechanisms and technologies already in place in web apps instead of inventing something new, despite every developer's innate inclination to do just that. Native mobile developers have to code something specific to make web-based authentication work, that's the point of this presentation. Learn about authenticating mobile apps against web servers using OAUTH, HTTPS, NTLM, derived credentials, and anything else with a snazzy acronym. Demonstrations will use your platform as long as it's iOS or Android.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Mobile Authentication in the Web World

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Why do we all know a developer who has been pounding out unmaintainable code for a decade or more? Why do people "believe in TDD but I don't have time to write tests during crunch?" How is it that we have an entire industry based around rescuing teams from acutely awful Rails apps?
It's because on the job experience is a poor teacher; plateauing as soon as the developer is able to ship code that meets requirements. Schools teach Computer Science which is only tangentially related to being a developer and most kata's are approached incorrectly, giving no value at best, and reinforcing poor practices at worst. On top of all this, our pairs (for the lucky ones who pair program) probably have not shown us anything new in months.
This presentation will give specific, concrete steps on how to slowly and steadily improve our game through practice and hard work. I'll identify what skill Rails developers should be focusing on and walk the audience through how to target and eliminate these weaknesses so that nothing but white hot joy streams out of our fingers and into our apps. There's no magic here, no secrets, and no hacks; just you and me working our butts off until we suck a little less.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Nobody Will Train You but You

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: An important part of any mobile application is being able to send it notifications and trigger updates that present timely information to users. Azure Notification Hubs allows you to easily do that for Android, iOS, Windows Phone, and Windows Store applications at scale. Along with the ability to deliver to millions of devices, you get powerful capabilities like push connection management, push templates, tag based registrations and delivery, and much more. All of this with up to a million pushes for free and no need to store data in the cloud!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Pushing to All the Devices with Azure

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Bitly users create 1.3 million short links per hour and click on 8 billion links a month. How would you store all those link mappings? How would you analyze the metadata for each of those click events? How would you identify and filter out spam in real time? How would you efficiently track, sort, count, collate and deliver reports on all the permutations of data that you want tease out of that activity?
Bitly makes use of a wide variety of tools & technologies in its stack and each of those tools was chosen for a reason (sometimes, even a good reason). In this session we'll walk through the Bitly stack and explore the reasons each component was chosen for the given set of tasks it performs. We'll discuss Python, C, Go, Tornado, Memcache, NSQ, Hadoop, Riak, Redis, Elasticsearch, Jenkins, Fab, Excel, and more. Ok, maybe not Excel.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The Bitly Stack: "What did you use and when did you use it?"

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Are you new to the professional world of software development? Do you have new developers on your team? Are you wondering why college and the School of Hard Knocks did such a bad job preparing you to be a functional member of a high-performing team? Take some advice from a junior dev who has walked the path and learn to avoid rookie mistakes. Learn the skills employers value and how to get them. We will discuss quick return actions that can be undertaken immediately, as well as long term, slow-burn investments in your career. This session will focus on technical and interpersonal advice to help make your first job search, entry-level hire, and first year as a developer go smoothly. A great career won’t just fall into your lap. It takes dedication, skill, persistence, and more than a little luck. Happily, we make our own luck.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The Junior Developer Survival Guide

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Asynchronous code is awesome, but it presents some unique difficulties for unit testing. Come to this session to learn practical techniques for unit testing code using async/await.
You'll first learn how to conceptually model async/await, which helps you avoid the most common async problems. Moving on, this talk covers the current state of async unit testing in various frameworks and libraries; and tips on how to properly mock/stub asynchronous code.
By the end of this session, you will have a full grasp of how to unit test asynchronous code, and you'll have an arsenal of techniques to address even the most complex scenarios.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Unit testing asynchronous code

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Google recently changed the landscape of home media with a $35 device the size of a pack of gum. Perhaps more compelling is that this device has made it easier than ever to develop applications for the television. This talk will translate your existing, well honed web development skills into the tools necessary to reach the largest screen in your living room. Green slime will not be included.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: You can't do that on television! Developing apps for the Chromecast

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Paul Middlin] There's more to screencasts and videos than showing Dylan how to correctly merge in changes (again). In fact, there are so many awesome ways to use videos that we thought we'd make a session out of it. Through the classic magic of slide-scrolling, we'll leap over time sucks, untangle the vines of confusing directions, and battle the beast of endless questions. Together, we'll save the princess! Er... level-up our communication powers. I mean, it's pretty much the same thing... Right?
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: 15 Uses for Video: A Developer's Guide

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Presented by Josh Holmes] Abstract is coming. We will be presenting with our partner about patterns for behavioral learning using data collected by many IoT devices. With our partner, we will be running a demo during the conference to collect sensor data relevant to the conference and displaying on a conference dashboard and potentially a mobile app.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Analysis of Big Data coming from IoT

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Presented by Anthony Eden] Distributed denial of service attacks are on the rise and their size and scope increases with each attack. From the recent attacks on Sony by the Lizard Squad, to attacks against a variety of DNS providers, including DNSimple, 2014 was a tough year for infrastructure service providers and consumer-facing services alike. In this talk I will describe various types of DDoS attacks, how and why attackers use them and how you can defend against them. I will talk in detail about the attacks we saw in 2014 at DNSimple, how we detected them and how we are dealing with them. Finally, I'll talk about the future of DDoS defense and the challenges we face in 2015 and beyond.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Anatomy of a DDoS and Defense Techniques

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Presented by Craig Courtney, Stephen Langella, Scott Oster] In this presentation we will provide a recipe for building modern healthcare solutions. We will discuss each of the ingredients (Culture, Architecture, Technology, Platform, and Practices) in our recipe and demonstrate examples of how we used this recipe to deliver value for our customers.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Building Modern Healthcare Solutions

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Presented by Kyle Tyacke] During this talk we will cover a high-level overview of WebRTC and the general architecture behind it. Then we will discuss the Respoke Javascript library, look at how it simplifies the process of implementing real-time audio, video, messaging, and data into web applications, cover a few code samples, and wrap up with a bit of Q&A.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Communicate All the Things!

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Presented by David Neal] Kanban is just sticky notes on a whiteboard, right? Whatever work you do, you have a process for that work. Be it software development, operations, services, recruiting, marketing, event planning, or professional cat wrangling. Kanban harnesses the power of visual information to turn your work into brain candy (or bacon). Yet, there is much more to Kanban than visualization. In this talk, you will learn the core principles and practices of Kanban, and maximize its potential to evolve how you, your team, and your organization works.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Do You Even Kanban?

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Presented by Benjamin Winkler] Every industry has its own culture and jargon, and health care is no exception. Not knowing much about a different field can make employment or contracting opportunities there seem less attractive, or even inaccessible. In this session, we will present an overview of the health care field for IT professionals. From NCPDP and PBMs to PHI and EHRs, we look at how the industry works, what technologies are commonplace, and how it is all interconnected.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Health Care IT 101

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Presented by Mark Miller] Learn how to write C# and VB code quickly and with great efficiency using CodeRush for Visual Studio. See powerful code building features including code templates, consume-first declaration, powerful refactorings, advanced navigation, selection, & clipboard tools, background code analysis, a full-featured test runner, the debug visualizer, a smoother Intellisense experience, and so much more. If you’re interested in seeing what CodeRush can do for your productivity and for your team, be sure to see this session.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: High Speed Coding in Visual Studio with CodeRush

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Presented by Jay Janarthanan] Golf has Tiger Woods and Jack Nicklaus; the programming world has its own list of superstars. These are the guys running the start-ups and working in lead spots at Google and Facebook. You see, anybody can tee up and swing, but only a few hit it on the green every time. As Robert C. Martin said, the top 10% of developers can write more code then all the other 90% combined. How? The greats—golfer and developer alike and these skills can be learned. In this presentation Jay will cover 10 ways any developer can become a highly productive developer.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: How Productive Are You? Top 10 Tips to Be a Productive Developer

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
[Presented by Bill Klos] On your way to work one morning, you walk by your favorite coffee shop. As you walk by, you notice a sign in the window with the day's specials: $1 off Lattes today! That's nice, but maybe Latte isn't your favorite…
Now imagine this...
Same scenario, but as you approach the coffee shop (let's say 100 feet away), your phone suddenly notifies you with the following message:
"Good Morning, Chris. Your favorite Cookie Crumble Mocha is only a few steps away. Stop in and we'll take $1 off your total!"
This is a much more direct, targeted, and context-aware approach!
By using Beacons you can make a huge impact to Customer Service, Revenue Generation, and Operational Efficiency. In this seminar you will learn what Beacons are, their implications in various industries and implementation strategies.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Micro-location with Beacons: Navigating the way with Mobility, Big Data, and the Cloud

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Presented by Tony Milne] Using tools you're already well familiarized with, let us show you how to leverage Microsoft's cloud-based Power BI. We'll show you just how easy it really is to discover your data and mash it with other's. Then, check out some easy-to-create awesome visualizations. But why keep the results to yourself? Share your work with others and collaborate on the results. Need faster results? Try asking Power BI some real questions in the Q&A. All this and available mobilization without any high up-front costs? It's true and we'll show you.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Need high class BI on a budget? HMB can help.

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
[Presented by Peg Bogema and Dave Sweeton] Process is one of the most misunderstood aspects of software development. Period.
Twenty years of experience in software development has shown us that lack of process is one of the most prevalent reasons why projects fail. Lack of process permits introduction of random change, fosters scope creep and allows for an inordinate amount of focus on one aspect of a system rather than the overall success of the project. Our experience has also shown us, however, that proper application of the RIGHT process for a specific scenario can be crucial in delivering successful projects on time and within budget.
This session focuses on the role of process in the software development cycle. It discusses a number of the well-established processes available in our field (Agile, Staged Delivery, Evolutionary Prototyping, Waterfall, Code & Fix, etc.) and points out the pros and cons of each. Rather than pitching the fabulousness of a single particular “silver bullet” approach, this session demonstrates how drinking the kool-aid of a specific process and then trying to ram every situation into it is faulty. The session is designed to help Software Development Managers and Team Leads recognize that there is no one “best” process – not by project type, nor by team size, nor even within a single company. It will not only help participants understand the pros and cons of the major established processes, but will also help them identify which processes are best suited for a variety of common development scenarios. By the end of the session, participants will understand why the most important aspects of process are (1) picking the right one for the situation, and (2) adhering to it once you do.
This session is one in a series of Stout Systems’ new educational seminars that are geared towards what we call “The Accidental or Reluctant Software Development Manager” … someone who has been thrust into the role of managing a software development team, often against their wishes and with no formal training in the unique challenges of that role.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Process?!?! We Don’t Need No Stinkin’ Process! (or “Why Process is Crucial In The Software Development Cycle”)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Presented by Ed Holachek] A typical switch is say an office setting is commoditized and easily replaceable, if it goes down, at most a day of production may be lost. A Rockwell Automation STRATIX switch features on board management and the ability to upgrade firmware & software features. Our STRATIX Team designs, develops, and deliveries scalable, redundant industrial Ethernet communications solutions that connect the machine or device in automated environments to industrial Ethernet. Featuring Cisco IOS as the core software, Rockwell Automation adds Unique, easily configurable industrial management software and communications protocols and the STRATIX line serves as the glue that ties processes, motion, and production together.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: STRATIX Product Spotlight: The Perfect Marriage of Hardware, Software, and Firmware

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: [Presented by Matt Van Vleet and DJ Daugherty] Last year we hacked a Tesla, this year we thought we would take it a step farther. We will try to hack together a robot that can transmit 3D video so that you can be working in any of our Clients or Forge Locations and interact with the others. Come see how a vacuum, Nerf Gun, Occulus Rift, and a 3D camera can talk to each other. It should be fun... come check it out!!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: We Built Our Own 3D Armed Telepresence Robot

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
WAI-ARIA's role and aria-attributes, combined with the rich capabilities of JavaScript allow rich Internet applications to be made accessible without any limitations for disabled users.
This session will explain the relationship between the DOM and the accessibility tree, give an overview of all the ARIA roles and attributes and how adding these to the DOM impacts the accessibility tree.
It will highlight the ARIA roles that work well across multiple platforms as well as the tricks necessary to get them to work consistently and cover 5 best practices for successfully implementing ARIA in a cross-platform fashion.
It will show an example of a gesture-and-keyboard compatible widget implemented using ARIA with annotated source code available for the attendees to get their hands dirty.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Accessible Web Application development using ARIA

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Testing in an agile methodology is the responsibility of the whole team. So if you are in an agile team then this talk is for you. To produce good quality software repeatedly and at an ever increasing frequency, means we all (not just testers) need to adapt. Believe it or not you can’t just test faster, but you can make smarter choices. More often than not, you must automate but automation does not solve everything. More fundamental to improving the testing is the techniques you apply in determining what to test. How to test them comes second. This session will cover ways to adapt your approach and offer practical examples of techniques to use to identify the areas to test. It will also cover testing approaches that can then be applied to test the areas identified.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Adapt your testing approach for agile

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: As software developers we should always be striving to give our users the best experience possible. It should be intuitive, responsive and above all fast! With traditional web technologies, creating applications that appear “fast” to the users can be difficult. To solve this problem developers have been finding new and creative ways to leverage the browsers client-side functionality. One of the most popular frameworks for creating a web application with powerful client-side front end functionality is Angular. Angular is a powerful client side data framework that lets you bind and manipulate data easily in a way that seems lightning fast to your users. And the best part is you don’t need to be a JavaScript ninja to use it! This session will show you how to leverage Angular with your ASP.NET MVC application to create applications that your users will love and you’ll love to build.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Angular for .NET Developers

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Like most things in life, there’s the easy way and the hard way. The same holds when working in cloud environments such as Microsoft Azure. The Azure management portal and Visual Studio can be great for those relatively simple projects, but quickly become very tedious when trying to create the multiple re-sources that often make up a real-world solution. In this session, we’ll demonstrate how to leverage various tools such as PowerShell, Azure Resource Manager, Azure Automation, and the Azure Management Library to quickly and consistently create full environments in minutes.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Automating Your Azure Environment

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: UI frameworks like Bootstrap or Foundation have a lot of perks: cross-browser consistency, ease-of-use, and visual design standards to name a few. However, they can be difficult to integrate into existing web applications in organizations with specific UI/UX vision.
