In this session, we will discuss our use case of building a custom UI framework named CoreUI at OCLC while working on WorldCat.org and WorldCat for local institutions. We will show the good (why and how we built it), the bad (roadblocks and traps to avoid), and the ugly (convincing a large organization) of building a custom framework. Attendees will get insight into our process, cross-disciplined approach and tools we used to build a true UI style guide; not just a UI framework. We will share concrete examples of how we built strict guidelines yet a flexible framework, maintained an encapsulated, non-intrusive code base and ensured code quality with builds, and produced a tiny framework size in the end.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Beyond UI Frameworks: The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Web developers are integration specialists; tying plugins, scripts and frameworks together into a web application that works. Thinking in terms of abstractions, by condensing many low-level ideas into fewer high-level ideas, allows us to simplify our code and reason about it with less cognitive overhead.
In this session we will examine a few techniques for building abstractions on top of popular JavaScript frameworks by building a Domain Specific Language and bringing some convention to our code.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Building DSLs using JavaScript/CoffeeScript

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Machine Learning can often be a daunting subject to tackle much less utilize in a meaningful manner. In this session, attendees will learn how to take their existing data, shape it, and create models that automatically can make principled business decisions directly in their applications. The discussion will include explanations of the data acquisition and shaping process. Additionally, attendees will learn the basics of machine learning on the Azure platform- primarily the supervised learning problem.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Getting Started with Machine Learning on Azure

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: You’ve made the decision to go out on your own. Do you want to stay an Army of One or do you strive for something more? Spend an hour discussing the obstacles you will encounter if you go it alone and the obstacles you will encounter if you don’t. Learn philosophies that will help you on your way to an Army of Two, from before, to during, and for after your transition to Employer. Move beyond Independent Developer, and switch from “Me” to “Us”.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Growth: Moving Beyond “Independent Developer”

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: ​In introductory artificial intelligence classes, every good nerd learns about ELIZA, a program which simulates a Rogerian psychotherapist using pattern-matching techniques. For example, a comment like "I hate my job" might get an answer like "Why do you hate your job?" ELIZA was famous for being one of the first programs to pass the Turing test, meaning that the dialogue was realistic enough that users assumed that it was a human and not a machine speaking back to them. This talk will introduce these basic concepts and history, and show an implementation of ELIZA as a Windows Store app for Windows 8. We will talk to her in a mock therapy session, so you will learn something about early artificial intelligence and perhaps something about yourself. :)
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: It's Cheaper than Therapy: Building an "ELIZA" Psychotherapist App

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Java EE 7 is here and the horizons for Java EE 8 are emerging. In order to solidly kick start Java EE 8, the GlassFish team conducted a series of community surveys. This session shares the content, results and analysis of these surveys. We will also share the detailed progress of Java EE 8 technologies already underway. The goal is to foster interest, discussion and participation around Java EE 8.
Some of the items covered include HTTP 2, Server-Sent Events (SSE), JSON binding, JCache, CDI/EJB alignment, cloud, PaaS, multitenancy/SaaS, JMS 2.1, JAX-RS 2.1, CDI 2, security simplification, REST management/monitoring, an action-oriented Web framework and much, much more.
You are encouraged to bring your questions, comments and ideas. The time to get involved in shaping the future of Java EE is now!
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Java EE 8: A Community Update

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Father and son makers Steve and Zack Sneed have been making cool, interactive Halloween games in their laboratory for the trick-or-treaters that visit their house. Each year, the game is a complete grounds-up build and gives the team the chance to hack together various cool technologies such as Wii remotes, pneumatics, servos, and computer vision. In this session, the Sneeds will cover the game design principles they follow and will show off some of the tech they've hacked together, including using OpenCV to build a game that uses $2 rubber balls as input devices to a zombie game in .Net. This session will be fun and the audience will be expected to play some of the games discussed.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Killing Zombies With Your GPU

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Reactive Extensions (Rx) has brought reactive programming to the mainstream in recent years with successful adoption in languages such as C#, Java and JavaScript. But have you ever wondered what Rx will look like as a language?
Elm is a new programming language based on the idea of Functional Reactive Programming (FRP). Elm lets you create highly interactive web applications without all the messy callbacks tangling around shared states.
In this talk Yan Cui will give a gentle introduction to Elm and share his experience learning the language and how he used Elm to recreate Missile Command in less than 250 LOC. You will leave this session with a handle on the Functional Reactive paradigm and a basic understanding of Elm.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: My adventure with Elm

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Scrum may have one the brand-war as the most popular of Agile Methods - but is it working? Or, at least, could it work better?
Standups become boring status meetings. Planning and commitments become command-and-control wishing followed by overtime. Testing stretches past the sprint boundary ... and that's just the beginning.
Matt Heusser shares insights into why Scrum adoptions are so commonly challenged in organizations, along with tweaks for how to get back on track.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Save Our Scrum (SOS)

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Just weeks after last year's Codemash, our community lost one of its giants with the death of Jim Weirich. Jim was a constant at Codemash and one of its most popular speakers. In this presentation, we'll reflect on the man and some of his best work:
- highly influential projects such as Rake, Rspec/Given, and Builder - software design guidelines that lead to cleaner and more maintainable code - applying lessons and patterns from one language to another - mentoring others to help them learn - the importance of hacking and curiosity
and more. Jim's work has made an impact on many and remains as relevant as ever. Come join us we look back on Jim's amazing legacy and how that output continues to prove valuable for us today.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: The Jim Weirich Legacy

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: KidzMash Kaboomz
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: KidzMash Closing

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
This talk will introduce developers to the MongoDB NoSQL platform and explain how it can be utilized as a robust data store alternative for your applications. We will discuss the concept of NoSQL in general and will walk through the basics of MongoDB and include many demonstrations of reading and writing data to a MongoDB instance via the provided C# drivers.
Throughout this talk we will compare and contrast the MongoDB concepts with the patterns traditionally followed in relational database systems such as SQL Server or Oracle. We will also share a significant amount of resources (books, blogs, links, courses, etc) that will make your adoption of MongoDB as easy as possible.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: A .NET Developers Introduction to MongoDB

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
The growth of node.js can solely be placed on it's community, and their ability to develop modules when a need arises. Developers constantly see ways they can abstract their code bases out into individual modules, which node.js has fantastic support for. In this presentation, Kevin Griffin will guide attendees through the process of creating a node module and distributing it in the Node Package Manager central repository.
Learning Objectives
Attendees will learn what the Node Package Manager and public vs private repositories. Attendees will learn how to develop their own node modules and how use them in their applications. Attendees will learn how to upload their modules to the central NPM database for public consumption.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Building Custom node.js Modules

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: This session takes a look at Android security from a developer rather than a hacker's perspective. Taken from the soon to be published book Bulletproof Android, we look at how to protect your Android code, how to use secure authentication in your app, how to communicate securely with any backend server and how to safeguard that server against attack. Throughout the session we'll use real world examples from the many audits we've done over the years to show how other developers have tried and sometimes failed to secure their code.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Bulletproof Android

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: C# is a great language, but our C# code is confined inside of our computers. What do we do if we want to control a motor or display information on an analog gage? We can use the C#, ScriptCs and the ScriptCS-Arduino library to interface with the world outside of the computer. In this session you will learn how to get started.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Connecting C# to Arduino and the world outside your computer

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: The cry from developers is unanimous: "I don't like Cucumber, my acceptance tests are brittle and hard to maintain!" And in fact, they can be. I'll show you in this talk what tools and techniques you should use to write independent, stateless step definitions that can be weaved together to form a testing DSL.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Cucumber Ain't Bad, You Are Just Doing It Wrong

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: The modern web has introduced new demands for performance that cannot be met solely on the server side, and Single Page Applications (SPAs) have rushed in to meet those demands. The SPA universe is full of choices (Backbone, Angular, Ember and more). What sets them apart, and how do you choose one? They all address the same problem set: rendering, routing, data-binding, event handling, composability and others. By dissecting how different frameworks approach these problems, we can investigate the quirks that set frameworks apart and gain a more intimate understanding of the SPA architecture itself. For beginners, ninjas and anyone in between, this talk can guide you further in the search for SPA enlightenment.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Deconstructing Single Page Applications

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Everyone in the pantheon of computing pioneers was lazy. Why else do you think people like Charles Babbage, Konrad Zuse, and Howard Aiken created the first computers? In this session, we'll explore the history of the first computers and the people who worked on them. We are in debt to our predecessors, and there is a wealth of information that we can draw from their lives and the computers they created. We'll learn about their approaches to problem solving, their breakthroughs and inspiration, and how you can apply these lessons to your life today.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: I'm not lazy, I'm a visionary: the history of computing

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Google Cloud Messaging (GCM) is a free service that allows you to send data from your server to your Android application. This can be lightweight messages telling your app there is new data to be fetched from your server or it could be a message containing up to 4kb of payload data. This demo intensive session will walk you through the steps necessary to implement push notification support using GCM inside your Android app. The GitHub repository for this session will be made available beforehand so feel free to bring along your laptop to walkthrough the demos during the session. The following topics will be discussed and demonstrated.
Prerequisites Set Up Google Play Services SDK Create Google API Project Add Google Play Services Library to Your App's Project Check for Google Play Services Availability Register Your App with GCM Test Server API Key and App Registration ID Implement App's Broadcast Receiver and Intent Service Process Notification Data in App's Activity Update the App's Manifest Testing Without a Server
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Implementing Push Notification Support in your Android App

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Kinect for Windows is more than just another fancy webcam and XBox One peripheral. Kinect is a 3D scanner, a directional microphone, infrared camera, and a whole lot more. This session will demonstrate the capabilities of the Kinect and show how easy it is to write your own custom applications. We will also explore practical business uses of Kinect and learn how this is more than just a gimmick gaming device.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Konnect with Kinect

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: Ever wonder why it’s harder to recall events at certain times, like remembering how to recreate a bug? Or why people are sure they have observed something they have not? These issues affect all people, including developers and testers. In his book Thinking Fast and Slow, Nobel winner Daniel Kahneman introduces two mental systems, one that is fast and the other slow. Together they shape our impressions of the world around us and help us make choices. System 1 is largely unconscious and makes snap judgments based upon memory of similar events and emotions. System 2 is painfully slow, and is the process by which facts are thought about consciously, carefully, and rationally. However, System 2 is easily distracted and System 1 is wrong quite often and is easily swayed by our emotions. These cognitive biases affect how people investigate, observe, and recall events. This session will, through a few interactive games, learn how cognitive biases affect one’s abilities to investigate, observe, and recall events (all skills good testers need). During those games, strategies are discussed to reduce the impacts of those cognitive biases.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Thinking Fast and Slow

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
Ruby is very friendly and a great choice for developers kicking off their careers. It is also a mirror. It reflects what you know about yourself. By exploring our own mental strengths and limitations, we can learn how to hone our skills to write amazingly better code.
While all examples are focused on Ruby, the techniques are all about you, the developer. The session will explain the psychological underpinnings of Don’t-Repeat-Yourself. With the groundwork framed we explore Tell-Don’t-Ask, Functional Core, and module/class/method naming with insights to help make good decisions balancing human mental faculties versus the capabilities of the computer.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: What to Learn After DRY, and Why

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: The closing ceremony/raffle will start at 5pm in the main dining room. It will have a different format this year. When you pick up your badge you will receive a set of raffle tickets. Keep the big stub as your claim ticket, and go to the dining room any time from 2pm forward to review what the prizes will be. You can then bid on the prizes you want to win. Put one ticket in ten different prizes, or all ten tickets in one prize. The drawing does start at 5pm, and you have to be present to win. Some sponsors will be doing their drawing as well. The family is invited.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Closing Raffle

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract: There will be some light appetizers, and some drinks, to give you time to reflect on your CodeMash experience, and say goodbye to your new friends. The family is invited.
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: AfterMash

PublicSessionDataModel.Abstract:
There will be two shuttles running loops through all of the official hotels. There is a scheduled loop during the morning and evenings, and an on-demand shuttle through the rest of the day.
You can use our website to track where the shuttle is, shuttle.codemash.org. You can see where the shuttles are in real time.
The shuttle will pick up and drop off by Entrance A in the conference center (near the attendee registration booth and the giant lion). The shuttle will pick up and drop off by the main lobby doors of each hotel. The shuttles are available to attendees and their families.
Afternoon: (Expect a delay) Call for Pickup Complimentary service to area hotels. Call Kalahari Concierge for Pickup (FIFO) (419) 433-7200 x34089
PublicSessionDataModel.Title: Shuttle
